Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however, the sick person is frightened by the cut: then it must be that you use your skill in cauterizing him without fear and without dread.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the measure of cauterization in that is not, unless with sharp water: and it is, that you place the head of the sick person in your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the tool we said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Next, receive the water I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and with it apply heat to the unextinguished sole of the foot, not thick or too thin, filling this tool's cavity with it, which has this shape.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the end of his extremity on which medicine is applied have a cavity, as the cavity of the cochlear radius does.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the tool with medicine over any one of them: and let the sick person lie on his side so that saliva from his mouth can flow out due to the intrinsic medicine, so nothing descends from it into the throat of him and injures him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	And hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you should apply the first of that amount for half an hour, until you notice it has already been weakened and calmed by the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take the root and enclose it over the radius extremity, and pour the root with medicine, and insert the root with the tool upwards into the tube until the root adheres to any part.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do that many times, until you achieve what you desire for cauterizing the useful one.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then release it: indeed, it rises and falls after three days or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you need to walk your medicine, do this repetition: and after cauterization, cleanse with the tip of a cone dipped in butter, and clean with what is there in its surroundings from the medicine: and wash it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And it is treated externally with ointments, and rinsed internally with gargles, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	So this is the nature of this kind of treatment - it is healthier and more prolonged due to the fear associated with the operation.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And sometimes it is treated with an instrument even finer than the cauterizer and scalpel: for it is treated with fumigation, according to this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take a pungent reed and hyssop, and origanum (oregano), and rue, and saffron, and chamomile, and dandelion, and similar herbs. Gather all these together or some of them in a pot, and immerse it with vinegar, and boil it. Let the pot be well rinsed out with a little sediment. In the middle of the pot make an opening through which the conical instrument is to be placed according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it out of silver or copper; and insert the end that has a small opening into the mouth of the patient until the steam rises up to the instrument above the tube, until the tube becomes darkened much.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this several times over her until she recovers.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful not to perform this treatment at the beginning of spring when the season changes.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Moreover, it adds to springtime: and you should not do that unless at the declination of spring when it is warm.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if this instrument is not available to you, then take a reed and compose its bark in the end of it such that the mouth does not get burned: because the bark of the rue prevents the steam from burning the mouth; and this is from good treatment with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the removal of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Head 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times it adheres in the throat, whether it be bone or a fish spine, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, you must extract what is above that which falls under the use of an instrument on your tongue, after pressing your tongue with the tool towards the sun, and you will then know what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And if what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, you must let the sick man eat first before food begins to be processed in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore, what is attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the sick person may swallow a fragment of the nap, or a root of lettuce, or swallow a small piece of dry bread: or he may take a fragment of dried marine sponge: and then he should swallow it, tying it with a string afterwards.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	And when it has reached the place where the thorns or bone is, and they are extracted, then it will come out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	And if therefore it does not come out with what we said: then use this tool of lead according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a finger slightly, and at the end of it have a curvature, which he inserts into his throat with ease: and himself hold its head up raised upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis, so that he does not have a cough and push the bone or spine out with it, or if needed, insert the doctor's hand itself.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But if the sick person inserts it, this is better: because of their knowledge about the location of what is attached: and push downwards or while holding his hand with the tool upwards, the entire thing according to its quantity which is prepared for him until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the Extraction of the Bloodworm.
Caput XXXIX.	Title XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When treating a bloodworm with what I said in the division of treatment alongside medicines, and if it doesn't respond, then consider doing this procedure in front of the patient's throat under sunlight, or after pressing their tongue with the tool I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your blow falls upon the bloodworm, extract it with a small hook or with slightly curved finer tools.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with them: then take a concave tube and insert it into the patient's throat up to near the throat. Then insert the heated iron part of the tube with fire inside it.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Perform this action many times, and let the patient abstain from water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him receive the treated water, cold, and open his mouth with it: and he should mix his mouth with it without swallowing anything from it; and he shall move the water once an hour after another using his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	Indeed, the bloodworm falls off when it senses the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If however it does not come off with what we have told you, then fumigate the patient with bedbugs or with a wing using the tool we described for fumigating a snail.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Perform this action many times, because it will eventually fall off.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	The method of operation during fumigation is as follows: take a pot in which there are live coals with fire: and the pot should be covered with a cover, having a hole in its center: and the end of the tool is composed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then release the fumigation, and let the patient place his mouth at the end of the tube, closing his mouth so that the fumigation does not escape, until you know that the fumigation has already reached the bloodworm.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the blood sucker falls immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	And if it does not fall, then try the multiple repetitions of the steam bathing.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can bear thirst, and eat salty food, and herbs, and does not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore, it is necessary for him to leave with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the tool used to extract the blood sucker from the throat when it falls upon it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to tongs, like you see: unless there is this kind of curvature that enters the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird called the stork, in which there is the roughness of an emery wheel: when it grips something, it does not release itself entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	¶ On the incision of abscesses, and their sectioning, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	The species of abscesses are many, of various kinds, according to how their memory is brought back, namely one and this one in this book: they differ in penetration of them and in the sectioning of themselves by two methods.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One is from the species of abscesses within itself, and that which it contains due to humidity.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is because of places where it occurs from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because an abscess occurring in the head is another from an abscess occurrence in the anus: and an abscess occurring in a fleshy place, is another from an abscess occurrence at joints: and each of them has its own judgment according to their operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And among abscesses are those that should not be punctured until after the maturation of the healing in them and its completion: and from these there are those that should be punctured while they are raw and do not mature according to completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like excrescences which are close to stitches.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because when an abscess occurs near the stitches and extends to its point of origin until decay sets in around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves might be affected by the operation. This is why that member experiences a closer degree of contraction.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or if an abscess occurs on the main member: because if you delay incising it until it matures, it may harm either him or through that main part of the body.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or if it's near the anus, then puncture the immature one: and there is no need to incise an abscess that is raw, incompletely digested, except when it's near the anus so that it doesn't putrefy deeply and spread into the inner parts of the anus, causing a fistula or result in a terminal stage that won't heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the time for perforating an abscess when it has matured according to completion: and this can be observed at the suppression of pain, the subsidence of fever, the fading of redness, and diminishment in pulse, and sharpness of headache of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same perforation below the abscess and at its more prominent parts. And let the perforation go through longitudinally in the body if the abscesses are located in hand and foot regions, cutaneous lesions, cords, nerves, arteries, and finally in all equal locations where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those that reflect, make the incision following that part of the body.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when the abscess is in fatty areas: then it's better to allow digestion of its contents until confirmation, as we said according to completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you pierce it before that, the course of the poison proceeds from there, and there are many ulcers and suppuration, and perhaps the lips become hardened, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some stumps are pierced according to the width of the body for necessity: or according to where the part needs it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And you should administer a small incision for small blisters and a large incision for large blisters: or many sections similar to the size of the blisters.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are blisters where it is necessary for the skin to be concave: and one strikes when it has already become like a patch, and finished at a point that is already dead: as what happens in many cases, such as pus and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among them are those that are cut with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from them is derived the manner of incision as if it were shaped like a leaf of myrtle.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As for the groin blister.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those where a circular cut and a crescent-shaped cut (lunar section) is administered, and similar ones from cuts.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But for those that do not have a head, such as the shallow superficial blisters, it is necessary to pierce them with a superficial or merely flat incision.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when there is a large blister that has already accumulated much pus, it must be pierced so that you do not overdo it and remove all the pus at once. Instead, extract some of it from within itself.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then soak the blister until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some more from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Perform this procedure multiple times according to the scale until all is released out. Especially if the patient is weak in strength, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man who is decrepit: for with each discharge of pus, the animal spirit is resolved from the animal many times. And perhaps the sick person dies and you do not notice it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, take this chapter as a major caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your perforation, at the point through which you have perforated, it is necessary that you cleanse the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound from the needle is small, or there is a flat cut, then administer flax oil, or old tallow.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is a large abscess and many perforation裂缝 are present, then you should introduce flax oil into all the cracks until it reaches the inner part.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you cut off a part of the skin in the abscess, or hollowed it out: then it is necessary to fill it with old tallow, or as when weaving cloth, or after pulling out wool from flax without moisture: and tie it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then release him, and care for that which needs to be done with the balm until he is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	And if there happens to be bleeding during your time of operation, then administer cold water and vinegar, after soaking the cloth in them: and place it over the bleeding area multiple times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	And if bleeding persisted, then it is necessary to administer a regimen and care, as well as powders which I have narrated in many places of this our book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	And if it is during winter and the area of the abscess contains many nerves, then you should pour on powders mixed with wine and warm oil, and place them over the areas.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is during summer and the areas are fatty, then you should place powders that have been soaked in water and oil, or use them with wine and oil, and make all of that cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Once when it will be the third day, as we said before, then you must remove the pustule, and cleanse it, and administer to its care what is suitable for it until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from knowledge of the general treatment of pustules.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the second part of the division, I have already spoken about every pustule, how the way for its particular single treatment is described in a chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Section on pustules that occur on the head skin.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small pustules occur on the head skin, and they are from nodum species which contain coats that are their sacks: as if they were swollen chickens.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	They are of various kinds: some of them are fatty; and from them there are those that contain a moisture similar to mud; and from them there are those that contain a moisture similar to froth and curd: they are like these, and among them there are those which are stone-like hard.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And when it comes to the section of all and their removal, there is no fear since at their section, an artery does not oppose in a contrary manner.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The procedure for their section is to experience it with the tool that comes after this, which is named the Intrusive Instrument, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if that which contains moisture is the case, then when it is cut during its section along its length, it should be cut superficially: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the cut from line b to line g. As soon as moisture is drained away, then scrape off the lump that contains that moisture, and do not leave anything behind on it completely.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times it returns, if anything remains from that.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the wound in Egyptian balm if it is present; and if not, in water and salt: and fill it with this, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will decay what remains of the infection.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then spread the Egyptian balm over it twice more, and three times, and if you lack that, until you are sure there is nothing left from the infection. Then treat the wound with the balm until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	And if it contains a fat lump: then cut it according to this shape, having the form of a cross-section: and remove the corners between the sections, and scrape it from every part: and try your skill in extracting the membrane that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	And if an artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you next.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do with the boil if it contains stones, from the section and treatment being the same, as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And cutting through the boil containing stones is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain boils located on the head in some people, in which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	This is what happened: for I cut above the boil on an old woman's head and found a boil like a hard, solid stone, rough, white, which could not be split. And whoever struck it while trying to remove it would wound himself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other boils that occur on the head, apart from these specific boils that happen on children's heads and at the base of the ears, the sectioning of all such boils should be superficial.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Simply make a puncture always from the lower part of them, so that the course of healing may move downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it along with what is suitable for their healing process.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	¶ On sectioning the Strobilus in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses occur frequently in the neck, under the axilla, and groin; and sometimes they occur elsewhere in the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And concerning those that occur among them in the neck, there is one and many of them: they are generated by each other; and every Strobilus is within its own proper membrane as it is in the nodes and abscesses of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the forms of these Strobiluses are numerous.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And among them are stony ones: and among them are those that contain moisture: and among them are malevolent ones, which do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In the one among them that you see with good disposition in touch, whose manifest characteristic is near to the color of skin, and it moves throughout all parts, and it is not attached with neck nerves, nor with muscles, nor with artery, nor it is deep: it must be removed by sectioning superficially from the superior part to the inferior body part along a line, b. to line g., and remove it from every side: and extend two skin flaps with a scalpel, or with multi-bladed scalpels if needed, as we have mentioned in head abscesses and outside of it, remove it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And above all caution, do not hit the vein or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the knife not be too sharp: so as not to injure your own hand with the cut, or disturb the patient, and hit something that is unnecessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you come upon a vein, or an artery, or there's an obstacle to the operation, then place in the wound a powdered substance, or certain powders that disperse blood, and tighten the wound, and remove it until the pain of antiseptic subsides and the wound softens: or it may begin to desire putrefaction.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	The blood is removed by suction, therefore proceed with your operation until completion.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Next, with your finger, check if there's anything left from the Strophula in other corresponding parts: therefore cut them and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If there is a large vein in the root of the Strophula: then you must not cut that Strophula from its root. Rather, you should tie it with a doubled strong thread and let it go until it falls by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with the old cote, which you have already prepared in the Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole Strophula is encountered, then you must join the lips over two wounds: and then immediately cut it off as soon as you see that there's no excess left.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If however you see that the excess remains due to the size of the Strophula, then you must proceed with cutting its root and removing it: and administer the suture which we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And that which contains moisture from the Strophula, puncture it with a superficial incision: so you will see its maturation site: and place the puncture below the part of the body following this, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the puncture, licorium with ointment and similar remedies, so it may heal what remains from corruption, until you see that the wound has already been cleansed. Then care for it with regenerative flesh ointments, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	The section on the division of the epiglottis in the case of an asp bite occurring within the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Title XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They said that the ancients made this incision in the epiglottis, and no one has been seen in our land who performs it: and here is the written account of their language.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	When they have a synanche (a condition), the division of the epiglottis must be done: because nothing improves through this method: for all veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a warm pustule in the mouth, or throat, or in both tonsils, when there is no discomfort in the passages, it must use the division of the epiglottis, to avoid the destruction that comes from pre-ignition.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we make that (referring to a previous procedure or condition), we must divide the epiglottis under three circles of the epiglottis, or four, with a small cut across its width, in the area between two circles, such that it is a cut in the sifacum (a type of tissue layer) and not in the cartilage: and indeed, this location is suitable for division as it is free from flesh and the blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then he should spread the throat skin with an instrument called an uncus (a kind of hook).
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should find the skin until he reaches the passage (the canal): if he sees anything from there, it is necessary to divide the blood vessels.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the sifacum (the mucous membrane) as we have described: and it is indicated after the division of the canal from the phlegm that comes out of there, with what breaks off, and the removal of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And after a certain period, open the wound.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	And when the hour comes to fear the pre-heating, join two lips of the wound on the skin, and take out only that part itself without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer the medicines which cause flesh to be born (or: generate), until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis said.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this discourse that we have narrated is an explanation only when one sees that a certain amount of these medicines has been swallowed by the sick person: and the sick man rises above death and wants to be cut with his breathing: they go to the second epiglottis, so that the sick man breathes over the wound site with some respiration, and is saved from death: for this reason they commanded to leave the open wound until the malice of illness is consumed, and the malice of him is three days old, and as it were. Then therefore they ordered to bleed the wound and care for it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this is what I have seen with my own eyes, that one maid took a knife and sent it into her throat, and struck against the part of the bronchial canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was summoned to treat her and found her groaning, as if the groan of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I then examined the wound and found that only a little blood had come out of the wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	So I concluded that she did not constrict the vein nor the artery; and the air was escaping from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore treated it, her wound and cared for it until she was well: and nothing happens to the maid except wheezing in her voice: and she returned after days to better dispositions.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	¶ On the section of the neck hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 42.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess is named Gastroceles, it is a large abscess according to the color of the body, and it occurs frequently in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it can occur in two ways: either naturally or accidentally.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, in the natural case there is no defect.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	Accidentally, it occurs in two ways: one of which is like large lumps.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other method is similar to an abscess that forms from arterial pulsation.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is fear with it, and it is not necessary to presume upon it with iron unless in the part that is small. And you should test it, and investigate it with an introduction (of a tool or instrument).
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to a large lump and not suspended by any vein, then cut it like lumps are cut. And extract what is contained within from the gland if there is something inside; or else examine everything of it completely.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the area with what needs to be from treatment until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	¶ On the section above the type of Lumps.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many species of lumps and I have already mentioned all their species in the division. And it is necessary that I mention here the differentiation between a lump and an exit (or protrusion), which causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore that when an exit (or protrusion) is a warmth and fever, and severe pains until the overflow stops and the corruption is completed; then indeed the fever and heat cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the knot does not have warmth, nor fever, nor pains, and it contains them inside like a sack which is their own proper organ, and its color matches the body's color: and they begin like chickpeas, and develop as lentils, both larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they come in two kinds: either they become fatty; or they retain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colors of moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	So when you come to the treatment of the Node, you must examine it, and first inquire about it with a tool called an Intromissum, according to how its form will be described in the chapter that follows this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of investigating the question and all nodes is, you should take this tool, and introduce it into the moist area that you find in the node: then move your fingers with it gradually until you know that the tool has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then place your last finger according to the size of the node.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	And then remove the tool (Intromissum), and examine what comes out in investigation of it.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If moisture flows out, regardless of its color: then dry it off with a superficial cut, as I said in the other nodes.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out in the investigation of the Intromissum, then you will know that it is fatty. Dry it off with a section having a form like a cross, according to this shape as I taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape off the skin from all sides easily: and if possible keep the sac over it so that you can extract both of them (the lump and the affected area) healed together.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If indeed it is broken by the pincers during surgery, and it's not possible to extract it intact, since this happens quite often, then quickly remove that fragment until nothing remains from it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains even a little bit, or much, the Knot according to most returns (for treatment).
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	And if it binds you and leaves a little bit: then fill the wound at your completion with some corroding and sharp powders: and pinch the wound, and put above it what sits an warm pustule, and care for it along with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	And if therefore it is a large Knot, then cut two of its lips, and care for it with what makes flesh.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however it is against you a pulsating vein, or not pulsating: then press forward, and fill the place with a small amount of sand ground finely, and let that tightly bound thing rest for two days, or three, until the wound rots and stops bubbling: then return to apply to what remains from the Knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	¶ Concerning external instruments for sectioning and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	Among these there are forms of introducers, and they consist of three species.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For among them is the large one, and from them is the medium, and from them is the small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of iron with square ends that taper inwardly, so they facilitate entry into the pustule.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experimenters, and no, that is, perforators: and one of them is named burin, that is, perforating. And there are three species of it.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From these, there is a large one, and a medium-sized one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They agree that they should investigate through the stumps, discharges, and sinuses, as well as swellings, from what is between them in relation to the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And for others, they are made round, smooth, and soft, like large needles to which felts are attached. These might be made from yellow metal, or air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those that are made from yellow metal.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And even experience is gained with the use of black lead, which fits to test for sinuses whose concavities are reflections, so that they might be observed in relation to their own reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three types of these.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because from them there is a long one, and a medium one, and a short one, according to the size of the opening and constriction of the sinus.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of scissors, and there are many types of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because from them there are simple ones, that have a single curvature. And there are three types as you see: Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them there are Blind Scissors: and there are three kinds of these.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them there are Scissors with two curves, and there are three kinds of these. And from them there are Scissors with three curves, and there are also three types of these. All these are necessary in their respective places.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of Scalpels, which are used for cutting and scraping Nodes and stumps: and there are three types of these. Since from them there is a large one, a medium-sized one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	The ends that undergo section are sharp; other ends are not sharp. They are not placed like this unless they serve for the benefit of removal during fear of incision in Nodules, or of a vein: and through them, the sick is healed, and finds temporary peace somewhat akin to what he encounters at excoriation by charring.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magdeburg and they belong to three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made from air and resemble Radium with which alcohol is produced. In the broad end, a hidden point of the spatulum is located; in this, it flows into both internal and external parts when desired, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the spatulum that is hidden between the fingers during excision by charring: and these are not felt by the sick. There are three species, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the Windlasses with which blood flow is cut off: and there are three species, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of air or lemon, round, somewhat according to their length as you see, and let them be for subtlety.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these species of Windlasses be large and small with you: so that you may cut off blood at speed according to necessity, and then when there is no medicine present for you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you do not use them in the cutting off of blood everywhere on the body, and you use them only in fatty areas: like behind the legs, and thighs, and behind the arms, and breasts, and belly, and groin, and similar places, from fatty lumps, moist ones.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they make small instruments similar to chopsticks' blades out of them, according to their shape. These are used to cut blood when it flows from the phlebotomy site, or near a vein incision, or an artery. And sometimes they make round ones according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of human breasts which resemble those of women.
Caput XLVII.	Head 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes, the breasts of certain humans swell during the completion of sleep (that is, when they begin to wet themselves at night), until they resemble a woman's breasts: and they remain ugly deformations.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	So, whoever dislikes this condition, they must shave over the breasts in a lunar section according to this form from line b. to line g. Then scrape off all the fatty tissue.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the incision with ointment from cooked medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then stitch together the two flaps of skin over the wound and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If the breast droops downwards and softens due to its size, as it happens in women: then it must be cut in two sides at their upper parts with two similar cuts of the lunar form, where each is contained by the other at both ends until a larger line contains the smaller one, according to this form from line b. to line g. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two flaps and remove the fatty tissue, and administer what we have said about stitches and powders that are necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If you do not make the cut required for it, due to the discomfort of the patient or because of blood discharge: then you must fill the wound with a submerged cayenne pepper ointment and release it until that which remains from the fatty tissue is corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the puncturing of deformities, which happens under the scrotum.
Caput XLVIII.	Title XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These discharges that occur under the titillating (a medical term referring to certain symptoms) are from species of Strophularia which contain cysts, and among these are those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	As for those among them that contain moisture, they should be cut longitudinally at the lunar section, according to this shape, from line b. to line g. Therefore, when everything within the discharge is evacuated through the meatus (urinary opening), then fill it up with a new dressing and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the dressing is removed, and it is treated with a suitable ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	And if the discharge is from the species of Strophularia nodules, then cut above it as we said in the division above for Strophulas.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if the wound extends to this extent and expels pus, then apply a cautery to it, as we said in what was mentioned previously.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	§ On the topic of dividing discharges that occur due to an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Title XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it becomes consolidated, it often leads to a discharge: similarly, when a vein too becomes affected, leading to a discharge and swelling.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which one can recognize that a discharge and swelling is due to an artery or vein are as follows: because when it's due to an artery, the discharge is long and accumulates deep in the body; and when you press on the discharge with your fingers, you feel as if there is a rattling sound within it.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which occurs due to a vein is round and prominent on the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And section above this pustule is an error, and particularly one located under the axilla, groin, neck, and many other body areas: it is very considerable.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, its care should be properly regulated with iron, and that which is also present in the extremities or at the head, must also be properly regulated.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, regarding what is derived from them due to the expansion of the artery opening, find it in the skin section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with tongs, afterwards the artery: and free it from tunics until it is exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Next insert the point under it and make her penetrate up to the other side, and tie the artery with a doubled thread in two places, according to what I taught you in removing two arteries that are in the vessels.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between the two ligaments with pus, until all the blood contained within comes out, and allow the pustule to drain.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply the treatment that generates pus until the ligaments fall off. Afterwards, care for it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is a pustule due to the cutting of a vein, then you must hold your hand with what is possible from under the pustule with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the point under the place you held with your hand, and make it penetrate. And there should be a double thread until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie it with the pustule's good ligament: according to what I told you about the urinary ligament, tie it from both parts with its two ends.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you feel that the thread is to be removed, then insert another needle with a different thread completely at the incision site: press and tighten your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its center until when what is inside comes out: then cut away excess skin and release what was tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place over it the wool you have preserved in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment that is done with ointments and unguents until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	For the abscess that occurs due to the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Head L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in an artery and vein, similarly an abscess can occur in nerves: it happens due to a blow or results from excessive effort, and similar causes. And they often occur in auxiliary areas, heels, and in any place where joints move. It is a serious abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body and it can be found in many positions without causing pain. And when it is tightened with congestion, it feels like a fainting sickness within him.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess gathered deep within the body, rather it's under the skin and it can move to any part of the body, and it doesn't extend forward or backward.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, that which occurs at joints should not be penetrated with a tool.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps there will occur contraction, though.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that case, for what occurs at the head or on the forehead, skin it with a small incision.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If thus it is an abscess of few threads, then hold it with forceps and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook and incise it. Afterwards remove it, and attach the wound to with stitches: and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	¶ On the excision of appendices, which happens in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Title LI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There occur in some people, many times in their abdomens and in other parts of their bodies, what are called fungi, which resemble mushrooms due to their similarity with them.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is subtle, and whose head is large, and the lips of which turn.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it comes out in small amounts: and there is from them something that greatly increases.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed, I have seen a man, and in his abdomen there were two fungi, which resembled mushrooms more than other things: there was no difference between them, the whitish, small roots, and their lips turned inward, they could be found, and moisture always flowed out of them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore dealt with these, and found them to weigh almost X and VIII ounces in one, and about VI ounces in the other. The operation is performed through the incision of them, which you will then consider. If it is sickly wet, and the color of the fungi is white, wet, having a subtle root: then cut it out with a wide spatula, and ensure there is presence of cauterization with fire before your eyes.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For much blood is expelled during its excision many times: therefore, if blood overcomes you, then apply cauterization to it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	And if you see it weakened, frightened, and timid during the incision with iron, then take a wire made from lead that is twisted in the center, and apply it tightly using an athel (a type of medical tool). The method is as we have described, and release it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add in the fusion of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to bind the lead, whenever it is pressed into wax, until it is cut off, and falls of itself without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the wax is of considerable thickness on the root, then there is something to be feared and to be taken care of: especially what is inside the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible that you may hit its middle part.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it to ensure that it does not escape.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of it until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And be careful not to mistake the wax that is of a yellowish color, with few sensory qualities and an unpleasant appearance; for this is a cancerous abscess: and I will speak about it in memory of Cancer later.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Section on the care of the navel region.
Caput LII.	Chapter LI.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The navel prominence arises from various causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or it arises from cuts on the belly which are above the stomach, and issues forth through a wound in the belly or intestine according to where it occurs at other sites of rupture.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from the vein or artery as was previously mentioned.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from constriction of the windpipe within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it arises due to a cut in the siphon and discharges pus: then its color is similar to that of the body's color: and it is soft without pain: and its various locations are apparent.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it arises due to the protrusion of the intestine, then its location is more distinct with what we have narrated.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it disappears: then returns and possibly there is a sound with it: and it is greatly admired at the entrance to the bathhouse, and the effort is heavily exerted.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is due to humidity, it is gentle, then it does not disappear when you press it with your hand, nor do you compress or add anything.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	And if it is due to blood, then with these signs a pustule appears turning black at the root.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	And if it is due to immersed flesh: then the pustule is heavy, large, hard, and grows according to a single unit.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	And if it's due to wind, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation with it is that you should then consider if the prominence of the navel is due to blood from an artery or vein, or wind. In that case, you must refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and panic, as I taught you in the chapter where I said pustules due to an artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	And if the prominence of the navel is due to the intestine or furrow: then you must advise the sick person to hold their breath and stand stretched out.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	And then, with the signs using hot wax around the entire area of the navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then advise him to be raised up between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	And then surround it with broad spatula around the area of the navel over the spot you indicated with the hot wax.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend half a pustule downwards with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	And then bind it tightly around with a strong thread or with a sturdy silk ligature string: and let the knot of the ligament be loose.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle segment that has been stretched out above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If however you cannot find it already captured from the ligament: then pull out the small intestine, and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestines towards the abdomen. And if you find hair, then take it with a hook and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however the artery or vein is against you: then surround it with much (material or substance).
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert two strong threads into them. And insert two needles into the circumference you made around the incision in a manner of a cross, to make them penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the incision in four places above the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle, and let the area rest until the flesh becomes putrid when stretched: and it will fall off by itself: or cut it down when it becomes thin and putrid.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with what is needed from the ointment until it is healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the naris or opening of the belly button is high from the flesh, or due to moisture: then it must be that you should make a concave incision in the skin, as we said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And remove the blood or moisture that you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of it with what strengthens the area.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	¶ On the care for Cancer.
Caput LIII.	Title 53.
