Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut that from the root of the palm, and do not leave space for the corruption, until it reaches into the palm of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades there, then cut the arm at its elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	And if the corruption passes through and you see it around the elbow: then there is death for the sick person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer beyond that with healing, is the quantity of strength.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do this with a foot, when corruption invades a toe, then cut it at the joint of one. And if it reaches up to the heel bone, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it ascends to the knee, then at the joint of the leg you will cut.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no art in that case, except for discharge and leave the disabled to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of applying or gripping the limb, or tightening it, is to tighten the ligament below where you wish to apply: and then tighten another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let the assistant extend one ligament downwards: and let the other assistant extend another ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until all the flesh is revealed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut or tighten it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it must be that you lay the linen cloth on from all parts and does not touch the healthy area with the scalpel: and let there be a wound added to the sick person, and apply a hot poultice.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If however there should occur an internal flow of blood while you are operating, then quickly cauterize the area: or place some blood-letting powders on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until completion.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the wounded limb with the corresponding ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happens to him in his foot, this is the same event that I am telling you about.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	What happens is that a blackness occurs in his foot, akin to the effect of burning by fire: and this corruption first happens in his toe until it spread throughout his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He treated himself therefore after he saw the corruption advancing into his limb with the decay of him, which he found from his pain and burning: and it affected him at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time has passed for him, the same decay occurs in his index finger of his own hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to restore that excess with what I had placed over his hand after applying medicines for the purification of his body: the excess did not return, but began to spread to another finger; until decay started to occur on his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called me to cut his hand: but I did not agree to that, hoping for a response from him about the return of that excess; and I was also afraid that he might die at the cut of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the strength of the man was above the situation.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	So when he had given up hope of me, he returned to his land: and news reached me from him because it was close, and he cut off his entire hand: and he was cured.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not omit this narrative, except as an aid to understanding what falls under this type of illness, and as a representation by which it is understood, and according to which it is handled.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Section on the care of sinuses, and the quality of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Title 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in some fatty parts of the body and stretches out its space until it forms pus: then when it is drained or punctured, and what was inside comes out from the pus, leaving a vacuous place as if there were a container: and the skin above it behaves like a woven fabric that has now been finely woven. It does not proceed to the final stage of corruption, nor spreads into the mouth, nor into the nerves, nor into the ligaments. It deserves to be named Sinus: but is not called Fistula. However, if its space stretches out until it spreads the corruption into one of these membranes, then it is named as Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is for you to cut that skin completely as it would be peeled off: and especially when it has been made thin like a cloth; and trust that it won't adhere with the place because of its decomposition.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you hope it will adhere to the skin and does not follow that final corruption: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then take care with Clister: and it is what you should consider towards the Breast.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that flows from it has a foul odor: then use clister with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and zinnia, taking equal parts, they are mixed together in a pot: and they are boiled over fire until the medicine turns red: and it becomes like honey in thickness.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take what you need from it: and dissolve it with water and honey, and use the clister with it on the Breast: and tighten its opening, and release the medicine into it up to the amount of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do this for days until the Breast is cleansed, and remove the smell.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes you can use clister with ashes water when this medicine is not available to you: and it is that you take the ash of vine wood or the ash from oak woods: and place the water on it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then heat her up, and use the clister with it until you're sure that the Breast has been cleaned.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the weak cannot bear the Egyptian medicine or the ashes water, then use the clister with water and honey, which already has a little of ground zinnia mixed in.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or use the clister with honey and wine mixed, because of the properties of honey it cleanses and washes away: and wine makes the Breast adhere, especially when there is excess of coagulation and drying in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this repeatedly, and you trust that the corruption sinus is already removed: then irrigate him with what causes flesh to be born in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And this is how you receive it from the plaster of dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose oil, and wine that is tight-stoppered: or irrigate it with certain medicines and other ointments, whose properties I wrote about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	And if the Sinus orifice is narrow and doesn't accept the tube of the enema, then widen it with iron gently: or place a rolled piece of linnen in it coated with Egyptian ointment, or in basil ointment, until it gets wider.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly, if the orifice is even wide, then gather its lips together with suture: and extract from it an amount that can accept enema without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly, if the orifice from which pus flows is elevated above the rest, then dry it in a lower place within it so that it can drain pus down to below. Because when pus is constrained deep inside the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus somewhat below its level as you wish: then try preparing the limb with a preparation that facilitates the drainage of pus from it, according to how you are prepared.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to ensure nothing is retained within it from the pus at all: and take the consolidating medicines that are placed above the sign, compatible with what you desire.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a size that it can communicate with all of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	And then cut into the direct opening of the sinus hole with forceps, more than the sinus opening gently.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then, extend from the ointment strips onto the cloth another one, according to the size of the hole: and place it over it in a long position away from the sinus opening, so that pus can exit through it: and do not remove the large piece of cloth until after a few days once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	That one which is over the Sinus opening, that one you remove at all times to see what comes out from it due to pus. And by this means you will know whether that which flows out of it is much or little; whether it's well digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And after this, again examine the location of the Sinus, whether the owner feels pain in it or there is no pain, and whether there is a boil in it or there is no boil.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	Therefore, when your treatment is applied like this, and you see the substance coming out over the Sinus opening, then you will know that the Sinus has already adhered, or is approaching adherence. Therefore, then resolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you resolve the wound, then change another piece of cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however pus comes out from the Sinus over a long space finely, then do not despair of its adherence, for its healing is approaching. For there are people among humans who delay the growth of flesh in their wounds, and from them come those who act contrary to him.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however pus that is undigested comes out from the Sinus over many days, then you will know that the Sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If thus adherence of the Sinus is delayed and prolongs its course: then add to drying medicines, but let the doctors do this such that the medicine itself becomes wet in its substance and dry in its power: like the unguent of dyafinicon, when an excess addition is added to it from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from this final part of what is treated, it is that you take the unguentum dyafinicon and dissolve it with rose oil, and let wine of old age be applied to its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix that with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And similarly performs this operation when you do not have the presence of dyafinicon ointment, honey, when you decoct it until it thickens and uses it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloes, and frankincense: grind all of it together, and spread the ground substance over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then pour it over the substance, and bind it on the skin: and pour over it the honey that you have decocted, until it thickens: then grind the mixture and spread it over the substance, and place a piece of cloth over it and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with long aristolochia and the roots of celestial lily, and there is the lily: and herb flour, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them in their simples or combined forms, grind these and sift them: and spread the ground substance over the honey that I have mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the Sinus extends and is not cured by this method, then you will know that there is a deep corruption within it. Or perhaps it has caused an impression in the bones or other hard parts, or ligaments: then treat it with the methods for Fistular (a type of surgical procedure), as was previously stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	### On the treatment of Panaritis (a type of inflammation), and rubbing of nails, and insertion into a finger, and cutting.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is an abscess that develops under the thumb nail or foot toe nail, and perhaps it may develop in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When thus the condition of his thing extends, and care for its treatment is neglected, and it's treated with an application of heat: or if it gets spoiled, and pus is emitted, until the root of the nail rots: and perhaps it spoils her completely, and perhaps the corruption reaches to the mouth until there becomes a foul smell in him: then the end of the finger broadens, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When then you care for it, when we mentioned this in division and your care does not match up with that: then one must strike through completely with the iron what has remained of the excess from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then after this, cauterize the wound.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Indeed, an iron cauterizer is very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If however the bone is healthy, and there is even a nail intact, and the hollow parts of the nail are already pressing into the flesh towards the inside, and begin to sting it and hurt it: then you must place a fine piece of iron under the angle of the nail which stings the flesh, and push it up. Then cut that flesh with ease, and place what remains of the burned flesh from the medicaments over it until it is all removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of that with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If corruption has already spread into the mouth, then you must cut that mouth and remove it; for a rotten mouth never heals.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and decay advancing into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what was previously mentioned as a reminder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If it happens by scratching of the nail or impact: and there is a pain intermittently, then one must use a weak bloodletting first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp Spatulum instrument crossing from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care, so that the cut does not reach the flesh beneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain to the patient through this and it will be a cause of an increased amount of flesh growing in that spot.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then take care of the site with what soothes pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	But the finger that grows in some human hands may be entirely fleshly. Perhaps there are bones in some of them. And perhaps there is a nail in it. Some of them grow at the junction root or its natality may be in certain joints of fingers.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	The one that is born at certain joints of the finger does not move: and the one that emerges near the junction of the finger may perhaps move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Thus, for the one among them that is fleshly, its cutting is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	This means: so when you encounter it at its root with the broad Spatulum tool.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	The treatment for which arises in the junction's root, is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	So refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In the one that grows at the end of the joints in the finger, then you must cut into the first flesh with a round incision up to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then scrape the opening with one of those small scraping tools suitable for that task.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Recovery that happens between digits one by one occurs multiple times either from the birth of man, meaning it is born with him, or from the healing of wounds, or from burning by fire and similar incidents.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it must be that separation of this consolidation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them lice or cloths soaked in rose oil; so that they do not congeal quickly and separate them. Or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the affected area has consolidated according to what is required.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	Similarly, if there is consolidation involving some fingers with the palm, then dry off that consolidation according to how it is prepared and suits the figure of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	### On Cutting [Surgery]
Caput XCII.	Title XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are numerous veins that are involved, large, full of superfluities of melancholy which occur in many parts of the body: and most of their events are in the legs, particularly in the legs of those walking, working, and bearing load.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you perform the body's bleeding from black bile with strong bleeding on occasion.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then use the phlebotomy on the patient for this basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	However, the treatment of these with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is, let it be taken up, and the black blood be extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is to remove the vein, and extract all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	However, its section is according to this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First immerse the leg up to the knee with warm water for quite some time until the thick and fatty blood resolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the leg at the upper part of its thigh towards the lower part of the knee with the aid of a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein at one, two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Next raise, that is, draw the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the top. And it must be necessary for this purpose for a phlebotomist on the upper side first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail up to the bottom: until an amount of blood that you see is sufficient and which the strength of the patient can bear has flowed out.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie that part: and instruct him not to eat anything that generates black bile. And repeat the evacuations and phlebotomy when the veins are filled up and it is harmful for the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Wound the inside of the weak knee, if there are many hairs there.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce this into the bath: or immerse it in his legs with warm water until the veins redden and swell. Or, if there is no present bath, exercise him with vigorous activity until the member warms up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Next, remove the skin directly along the line of the vein by cutting longitudinally: or at its last part near the knee, or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Next, open the skin with pincers, and scrape the vein from all sides until it appears to your senses: and at its appearance you will see that it reddens as it darkens.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When the vein thus runs out through the skin, you will see it white as if it were a chord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce the probe under it until when it elevates and emerges from the skin: hang it with a blind, gentle hook.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Next, cut another section close to that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Next, elevate it with the probes as you did before, and hang it with another hook as you did first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Next, cut another section or more sections if you need them.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it and with the last section, cut into it at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Next, remove it up to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you extract it from the upper section or with all higher sections until when it completely emerges: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you to extract or elevate it, then insert a sharp needle with a strong double thread and tie it, and pull it out. Or if that fails, insert the rod beneath it, and move your hand over all parts until it goes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be cautious, so as not to penetrate too far.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you do penetrate too far, it will make the extraction of that thing very difficult for you, and it causes damage to the weak one from there.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it completely: then place over the wound a piece of cloth soaked in wine and rose oil, or just oil, and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	And if it's contracted, having a twist causing inversion to parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then you must fix over it to all parts of its twistiness, and the sites of that inversion.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you lift it completely: and be cautious near your section line not to pierce or wound her, for it will become difficult for you either to lift or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	So keep your caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of the Incident on Healing Vine.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of the Blind Knot.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not treated in the same way as other knots, nor does it have a sharp end that could pierce blood vessels: and it has a large bending, being soft. Because if it were fine, the vessel would be pierced by its thinness; indeed, it has superfluous bulkiness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Calf Vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the limbs on warm lands, such as Alzagi, and the land of Arabs, and on dry, warm, thinly fertile lands; that is, those in which no grass nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it might be generated in other parts of the body besides the limbs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Indeed, its generation is from corruption that happens under the skin, just like it happens within snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of this vein's outcome is that inflammation suddenly occurs in the limbs.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then, the area gets filled with pus.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then, the vein begins to emerge from that area of pus, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore the end of it appears from that, then you must suspend over it a piece of lead of which the weight is equivalent to half a Keil-drachma, up to two drachmas and mark this point: and remove the suspended lead from the limb.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something comes out of it to the external part, mark that on lead and make a mark for this.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it extends greatly, then cut off its part and mark the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut into it deeply before all of it has come out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut too deeply, it will contract and penetrate into the flesh. And this causes a boil to occur and decay in the area, leading to an evil ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore, it must be handled gently and extracted gradually until the very end of it comes out, so that nothing remains from it in the body: and this particular vein extends to a length of five palms and ten in some people.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it reaches me, for a man's discharge is from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	And if you happen to be struck during your time of medication: then insert the needle into its opening and puncture it through that opening longitudinally, together with the body, until everything from the material inside is evacuated: and apply putrefaction treatment at the site along with medicines for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	And then attend to the treatment of blisters afterwards.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein often has many branches, particularly when it appears at the ankle joint, or within the foot itself: and it has many openings, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So treat that part as we have said in the division, and together with what was already mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ Concerning the removal of worms generated under the skin, it is called Boil Agitation.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This condition is called the Boil Agitation in a certain region among us: because it happens frequently to oxen, and there is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it travels throughout the body, rising and falling: and it becomes evident to perception during its movement from limb to limb, until it breaks wherever it breaks into skin, and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its production is from the pus of some body fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just like how worms and snakes, that is, roundworms and hookworms, occur in the intestines.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its maleficence.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it travels through the body and rises to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens in him and comes out, and destroys an eye: and this happens frequently.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When then you wish to treat him and extract it, this is done only at his walking, and manifestation to his sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	So it is necessary that you tie what is above him and what is below with a strong bandage together.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it goes deep into the flesh and you do not find it: then put a cauterizing iron over the place until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And what is feared as greater is its corruption that spoils his eye, as we said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	And if you see that it has already penetrated to the head near the eye, then bind below it a good eyebrow constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary to use the sick purification of his body with medicines that dissolve bad putrid fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Section regarding the sickness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XC (Ninety).
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This sickness is called Nakir in our land: and it is pain that occurs in certain limbs, then changes from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have seen this myself, as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to attend a woman who is sick in some areas.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed me her arm, and I saw a slight swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I stayed there for an hour, I saw one swelling move with a stick, like a worm moving, ascending to her shoulder faster than it can be: as silver liquid when it runs from one place to another.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore leaves that place and settles in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then sit for an hour, and run throughout the rest of the body, until it reaches another part of the arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	He then told me that he was revolving within his entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was therefore amazed by the speed of its permutation from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed, before this, I had not seen this illness so much by my eyes in such a manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who find pain to be changing from one limb to another: and I did not see it with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is other than due to the fact that she was one of those from whom dry body veins are detected: hence it appears, by sense, that that windiness has been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delightful and have moist bodies, whose veins are hidden.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you seek to cure his illness, and the patient feels that pain: then if it is visible to you as we said, then bind above it, and below it quickly: and cut above it, until that constricted windiness escapes: and cauterize the area.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see it with your eyes: then attend to it along with the removal of the body, and that which drives away winds, and smother these with stinking pills, and pills made from serpentine, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	¶ On the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Title XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are differentiated according to their types and the locations from which they fall out of the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their variety is as follows: among them are those that have large points and small ones; concave ones, and blunt-tipped ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them are those which have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that fall according to the parts of the body where they hit are divided into two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or, the limbs are from the main body parts which are concave, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	So when it falls into any of these body parts and you see the signs of death that I tell you about later, then you should know how to extract that arrow from them, for death follows it wherever it is found, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these bad signs and the arrow is not hidden deeply within the member, then extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs when an arrow falls into the brain and penetrates the mouth, and emerges through the siphon above the brain, are: for accidents often happen from that such as fever, blindness, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, cramps, confusion, and vomiting bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may come out through the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech may be lost, and the voice destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the place of wounds, a white moisture is discharged resembling cream.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there issues forth something similar to bodily moisture.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore you perceive these signs, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are: it is close to the left nipple; and feels as if it is stuck firmly in something hard, not in a hollow.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of an arrow is like the movement of a pulse: and it flows out of the wound black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And this follows, the coldness of extremities, and cold perspiration, and intermittent fever.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So you know that death is certain to occur.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it pierces the lung is the discharge of foamy blood from the wound: and the symptoms that follow are choking, and the complexion changes to that of a sick person.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a large amount of air, high up: and he seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	And if the arrow falls into the pleura, which is in the chest: then it's near to the thin ribs: and there is a great gasping breath with intense pain, with sighing: and all the shoulder joints move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested will be discharged from the wound with food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls into the abdomen and is stuck there: something like feces or a wad, or an intestine that has already been ruptured will be discharged from the wound.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for his treatment, nor for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and urine flows out: and something proceeds from it to the external parts, and makes the pain greater than the weakness: then you will know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, spatula (a term used for parts of the body), assistant bones, vertebrae, forks (possibly referring to anatomical structures like joints or ligaments), thigh and similar parts are diagnosed according to multiple dispositions: when the arrow does not find an artery, or a nerve: and there is no poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I will tell you what I have seen about these arrows, so that you may understand through this in regard to your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	This is because some men, an arrow has fallen into the lacrimal sac of their eye, and at the base of their nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So extract it yourself from the other side, under the skin of his ear: and he will be healed, and nothing harmful happens to him in his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And he extracted another arrow for the Jew, which fell into the fatty tissue of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not find anything from it except a small part of its tip, with which it sticks to his own wood: and this arrow was large among arrows from the Turcoman bows, made of soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and nothing harmful befalls his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of the Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow, and that is the kind which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I followed it between two guides: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I have skillfully extracted her with care until she was freed: and the Christian is healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from him which had penetrated into his abdomen: and we thought he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	So after thirty days had passed for him and nothing changed from his condition according to his dispositions, I pursued the arrow: and I devised a plan over it, then extracted it: and he was healed, and no harm befell him afterwards.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom an arrow had fallen into his back, and a scar was formed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And after seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen into her abdomen, and a scar was formed over it, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing changed from her condition according to her dispositions, and the woman did not find any harm in herself with any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whom an arrow had fallen into his face: and the scar became consolidated, and remained, not finding much pain from it: and similar things happened many times.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from the King's official, which had fallen into the middle of his nose and was already moving towards the right side slightly: and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called to treat him after the case of the arrow up until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the scar from the arrow to be tightly bound.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I examined it carefully with a gentle touch and did not feel anything. Indeed, he himself was experiencing pain under his ear from the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Therefore, I hoped that that point was from the extremity of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Therefore, I plastered the place with a plaster containing a magnetizing and digestive property, trusting that the spot would be treated, and a sign of the arrow would appear to me, so that I could cut above it: and no accident occurred in the place indicating that the arrow had followed the spot.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	So I diligently treated it with plaster for many days: and no incidents occurred, and the wound hardened in the meantime: and it remained ill from its removal for a space of days, until he felt an arrow on a certain day within his own nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	So I applied for many days an acute, corrosive medicine to it, until it opened: and when I tried it again, and felt a subtle point of the arrow adhering inside the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the incision with that acute medicine until we could clearly see the tip of the arrow. And it took me about four months to complete this process.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move them without compliance towards exit: then I didn't stop using skill and devise methods with mechanical devices until that certain day when forceps were made at an appropriate size, according to their shape reaching the tip of the head, when I was able to extract it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that the nasal cartilage is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	So I restored it, and the wound hardened and was healed with complete health; nothing at all harmed it.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you about the quality of extraction of certain arrows: that you might place this rule and explanation above what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this craft and distinctions of them are not included with its narration: nor does this book include that, and a skilled artisan compares it with little to many: and with what is present, above that which is absent: and he discovers a new operation, and a new tool among descending phenomena of this craft when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	Therefore I say that arrows do not leave the parts to which they are attached, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or against the other side of the part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which leaves from where it entered, whether it is the arrow proceeding in a fleshly place: and it is drawn and leaves.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not conform to the exit from the time when it falls: then you must let it go for a few days, until the flesh around it decomposes. And his attraction will be relieved, and its departure.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is stuck in bone and does not comply with your exit, then let it go for a few days as well. And try it every day with its attraction and movement until it leaves.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	And if it does not comply with you for exit after days, then you must bore around the area of the arrow in the bone from all sides with a fine drill until the arrow expands.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw her and extract her.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the head bone, and has already proceeded into one of the brain cavities, and shows certain symptoms that I mentioned; then refrain from the attraction of the arrow, and let it go until its condition equates to this after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow has reached the lung, then death does not prolong itself for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless within bones of the body only and does not penetrate to the lung: and he remains sick for a few days, and nothing happens to him from those events: then his abilities are tested by the action of the arrow and its removal.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	And if it is deeply fixed and does not obey you to your attempt of removal: then administer arrows around the area of the arrow as I instructed you: afterwards take care of the wound until he is healed.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	And if the arrow has already been removed from the body and hidden from sight: then seek it out with your attempts.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	And if you feel it, then draw it out with certain tools that suit its removal.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	And if you cannot reach it over it due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep inside: and there is no opening, or nerve, or vein there: then wait until the wound enlarges and becomes possible for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	And if there are ears that hold it, then free the fixed flesh in them from all sides using every tool you can and any means possible. If this is not possible without causing an issue with the movement of flesh during fragmentation of the ears or twisting of them until it becomes manageable.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow in any place, then use the twisting motion of your hand with forceps to all parts until it is made to come out: and using the most subtle method possible so that the arrow is not broken, making its removal difficult both for you and by you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	And if you cannot remove it in one attempt, then let it be for a few days until what is around it decomposes.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat this: if the operation eases the ailment. But if the blood flow contradicts you, then administer what we said from treatment in his chapter: and keep your strength away from the cut of a vein, or nerve, or chord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the skill in every way possible that helps you aim the arrow: and let it be with ease, and calmness, or slow speed, and strength, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And you must do when pulling the arrow as it is weak according to the figure, according to how it was with the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	And the arrow that emerges from the opposite part of the other side, or begins to move towards it something on the outside: or creates a protuberance at the tip of the arrow through sensation from the upper part of the nearby skin, and you see it protruding: cut it above it, and make the cut according to the amount that can be taken with the forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it: for indeed it becomes easy for removal.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness until the arrow imprints in the bone and expands for itself: then pull it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let her go for days: then repeat this until she emerges.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	And if the arrowwood is in it, then push it with her.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wood falls and you are unable to administer a push: then insert that tool into it until its concavity enters into the tip of the arrow. Then push her with him.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push it with the tool entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The sagitta is understood through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then you must, if possible, hollow out all the flesh in which the poison is: if that is within your capability.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it according to what is suitable for this matter.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow falls in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or on the side, and it touches close to what you touch with your probe, and cutting it off is possible for you: then cut it, and remove from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and pull out the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then heal the wound if you see it, and take care of that until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of pincers used to extract arrows.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Their ends are similar to the beak of a bird, which is made like iron: when they grasp over the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	Many kinds of them are made, large and small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, its sharpness, and the depth of the wound, and the constriction around it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the impelling tool which is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the impelling tool for the deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is like the end of a staff for a deaf person, so that it can be inserted into the concave arrow and pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The end of the tool for pushing concave arrows is like a feather, so that it can be inserted into the arrow and pushed forward.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On Bloodletting Through Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	For bloodletting through veins, which is practiced within the body, there are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of which in the head are sixteen: two jugular veins which are behind the ears and are called 'the twos'; and two arteries that become apparent at the two temporal points; and two veins which are at the two nasal lacrimal points of both eyes, they are called 'the observers'; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidages, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins which are used for bloodletting in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it comes from the side of the axilla: and they call this common the head vein.
Et Fusca.	And the Dark One.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the Middle vein, and it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch: and they call this common the body vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica vein, and it is placed in the inner side: and it is also called Tinnitus.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And they call this common the belly vein.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial cord, and it is placed above the elbow: that is the one where bloodletting takes place, and that is the one which appears above the thumb in an obvious manner.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is a vein that is between the ring and the smallest finger: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And there are three veins in the thigh and in the foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the thumb curve coming from the lateral side of the thigh.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second one is the Saphenous vein: its location is at the heel, coming from the domestic lateral side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Nesse vein: its location is at the heel on the lateral side of the thigh.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And there are three veins like those in the thigh elsewhere.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding bloodletting, two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	For bloodletting, the two veins that are found after the ears are beneficial for old coughs, and headache, and earache, and bad sores in the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting is as I am telling you.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is to cut the head of the patient: and its scalp should be rubbed with a good friction using a rough cloth at the site of the two veins.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the patient hang his neck with galls (a type of leather) until the two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the ears at two depressed spots on the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So find them with your finger, and where you feel the pulse under your finger, there mark it with hot wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the bloodletting tool, which is called the Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	And then insert it under the vein into the skin until the bloodletting tool reaches the opening (the orifice).
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then raise your hand with the vein and skin up towards the top, and cut the vein along with the skin in the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be equal to that of two joined fingers, or roughly so, and allow as much blood to escape as you can.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with powders, and let it go free until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now precedes at the beginning of the book the cutting of them and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	¶ On bloodletting with two arteries simultaneously.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	However, two arteries which are useful for bloodletting in the times of phlebotomy are: and the hot one and the obturator, and a running exudate from over-abundant discharges to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting for them is as I am about to tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The invalid should have their neck bound tightly until two veins become evident through apparent manifestation; and there should be a pulse beneath your finger of them.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then the signs will appear with the cautery.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.
