Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you wish for them to fall, powder something from ground aloes, or salt, or ashes over them, and they will immediately fall.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	¶ The End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	A universal discourse on restoration, and dislocation, and treatment of twisting injuries, and similar conditions.
Caput I.	Head I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is frequently necessary in the art of Medicine, and it is about restoring fractures and accidents resulting from dislocations in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, my sons, that many are the proud physicians and common folk who speak of this chapter, those who have never seen or read an excerpt from the old book.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And because of this reason, it happens that this manner of knowledge from the sciences is absent in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never been fortunate enough to find anything good in it, and I do not gain from it what I would gain otherwise, only due to the length of reading old books and studying them until I could extract knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then by means of my experimental efforts and study over time.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have detailed to you all of what my knowledge contains from this chapter: and regarding what escapes the experience of myself, after I have abbreviated it for you, freed it from the occupation of elongation, abbreviated it at its end in abbreviation, and shown it at its end in declination. And I have formed many forms within it, derived from the forms of instruments that are used in this manner, when there is addition to declination, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	In summary and as a collection, we should consider the fractures of bones from which it is necessary for us to present beforehand before beginning our recollection of the fractured members, and various types thereof if each one individually.
Caput II.	Head II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	It is necessary that we state in the introduction of this chapter the main points to be discussed and chapters towards understanding which drive one's intellect first: namely, for you, those who are prepared, to know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say, therefore, that when someone suffers from a fracture, or dislocation, or twist, or any other accident, then you should first proceed to perform bloodletting on him and relieve himself, or both at the same time: if there is no prohibition by something else such as weakness of strength; or it concerns him who experiences something similar to these issues being young or old in a state of decline; or it is the time for intense heat or intense cold to greatly prevail.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then be content with his food, cold herbs and bird meats, and avoid alcohol, heavy meats, and filling up from foods or any food that fills the blood vessels.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Once you are relieved from the heat of fever and do not feel an outpouring of pus to the member: then the sick person should return to his first routine diet according to what his habit is.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When then the broken mouth begins to heal, the sick person should consume food that provides abundant nourishment, in large quantities and in heavy foods with viscosity. Such as foods made from cooked wheat mixed with water, rice, heads, feet, udders of sheep, eggs, and fresh fish. And thick wine, and similar items.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this kind of diet, the healing of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And you will know that broken bones, when they are found in men who are at the beginning of old age and declining, do not remain continuous and consolidate according to their natural tendency always, due to drying out of their limbs. And the consolidating and continuing aspects which are from them towards the end of laxity occur like the bones of children or young ones.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature connects over the broken mouth from every part something similar to a paste, in which is thickness, to which it adheres and tightens itself until it cements together by itself, and binds together until it reaches the end of strength and firmness, just as it was at first, until nothing prevents it from performing its operations: for this reason, it is necessary to put food for the sick in things that have weightiness, and viscosity, and thickness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you will know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of members: for example, a fracture of the thigh is different from a fracture of the skull bone: and a fracture of the rib bone is different from a fracture of the back bone: similarly, all other limbs are diverse among themselves: and I have come with the recall of all species of fractures explained in his chapter separately from each other.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the species of bone fractures are also varied within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Because there is a curved fracture, besides which asterisks occur in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes a fracture occurs along the length of the bone: and there are fractures known as asterisms, that is, stars, and additions proceeding, just as they are in a reed when it is fitted with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding: there is a fracture with a wound and breakage at the head, and there is a fracture of a small crack.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And for every species there is an art or a proper tool for its restoration, according to the recall of which it will be distinguished in its respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from which the fracture of bone is known, is its twist and its height; and its appearance to sense, and sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When then no twisting is observable in the place, nor sound when you touch the mouth with movement, nor does the unwell person find a great pain; then there is not there fracture, indeed it's possible that there is twisting or small crack: therefore it doesn't need to move it by hand and complete compression, indeed put over it from medicines whose recollection comes back, after that moment which fits the place: afterwards the constriction gets tightened subtly.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the area is curved and divided into two parts, besides what happens in it, all its portion moves from its partner: then you must begin from your own time to the correction of it, equating it before it occurs a blister hot.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	And if a hot blister should occur to it, then let the thing rest for some days until the blister is quiet.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equalize it according to whatever manner can be done by gentleness and ingenuity.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration of it, and its equalization, is easier than with bone where fractures occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then tighten it, according to how its recollection will come back to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	And if there are fractures in the bone, then an extension of this broken member from two parts is necessary, whether it be a hand or a foot: or with your own hand if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with rope and hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And let your position be when you place the member over an equal location, according to its natural figure, until when the parts of the broken member are extended: then try to make those additions by all ingenuity and any manner possible in their places: and beware according to your strength, lest there be pain or damage upon the unwell from your operation; and try according to your strength, to apply one or two bones with their own partner, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour, that you try and touch him with your own hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	And if you see anything different there, correct it, and adjust that by the measure of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of excessive stretching and strong compression, as many do with the duller patients.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	Indeed, many times it happens during their own operation that a blister becomes hot, or there is constriction in the body: as we have already seen from their operations on numerous occasions.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then attach after equalization, and suitable operation, and the constriction of that limb, and peace, and tranquility: and warn the patient about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him aware not to move himself during his watch hours and his dream at the turning of his body, its agitation, and during his state of weakness, and all his movements with the full strength that remains.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And let him be cautious so that the position of the limb does not follow pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	This is because when he feels pain or injury in the position of the limb, then it is necessary that you rearrange him to another position from that with which he did not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And be careful with him, so that his position is that one equal and straight: lest when he recovers, any distortion should happen in the limb.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the constriction of a fractured limb is as I describe it.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	Know that limbs broken differ in their weakness, and their size, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	So, those which are small among them, like the arm, finger, and thong, then it should be that there is a soft, delicate dressing.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	Those among them that are larger, such as the thigh and leg, must have a broad, tough inner lining.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because the broad ligament supports the large member and binds it from every side with an equal constriction, so that it does not penetrate itself by any means.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then, after your evacuation, start by applying an appropriate ointment to that, on the soft plaster over the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to roll the ligament over the site of the fracture three times, or four, according to what is suitable for the member: and press your hand with moderation against the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with it to the upper part from the site of the fracture, and press less than you did when you tightened the fractured area.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then extend yourself gradually with the rolling at the site of the fracture, and gradually soften the constriction until you feel a large amount coming from the healthy area.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another poultice and roll it again over the fractured area.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go with the rolling to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And let your operation be on the constriction of the rolling and its softening, as we said about the first rolling above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place the intervals with soft plaster or cloth, according to how it tightens the fracture if there is such tightness in it; but if not, do not put anything on her.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then roll another poultice over that one.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Then evacuate the area surrounding these rolls centrally immediately, if there is no swelling or blister at the site, and do not apply a warm compress.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	If there is a swelling or pus formation within it, then place over that which is seated the pus and remove the inflammation; and let her rest for a few days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then, bind over it at that time star needles.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And let the star needles be made from the middle parts of a reed, shaved and skillfully formed; or let them be made from wood which produces sieves, those that come from pine, or from geraid, that is, palm branches, or calingi: and let the width of all the star needles have this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, it must be that the star needle which is placed over it should be somewhat thicker and wider than the other star needles: and the length of the star needle should be according to what fits the size and strength of the limb.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then bind over the star needles with another thread in accordance with the first binding method.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind over with threads crosswise, according to what we said about binding: and it is that your binding should be thicker at the break site than when binding. And the more extended from the break, the lesser the binding.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it must be that the threads have medium thickness and fineness, and they should be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, like I've seen in the procedure of those who place thread made from twisted linen strings, there is a great mistake: because the binding falls outside its quality with them.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And very thin threads do not agree either: for you cannot follow through the binding with them what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it should not be that there is less than a finger's width between one star needle and the other.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the sick person is injured through the ends of his fingers after tightening in healthy places: then put under them something soft from a dressing or treated wool until nothing gets hurt from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When however there is fracture with ulna, and a disruption occurs in the skin, I heal it remembering its particularity in chapter two.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken limb needs to be bound with pins from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	This is because when a limb is large, it should not be put under itself pins until after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the risk of dislocation in hot baths.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of bandages that were used in ancient times to restore fractures and dislocations, which are applied over them.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The common method of bandaging abbreviated for restoration, suitable for various constitutions, particularly women and children: because it is on what heat does not dominate nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is that you take from the mill dust powder and the starch which hangs on the walls of the mill during milling motion: and make it as such, excepting sieving it with flour. And apply its mixture not thick nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	The other method of bandaging, for the restoration of fractures, dislocations, and twists.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Prescription for almond oil, laurel oil, acacia oil, wormwood and myrrh extract: take all the oils mentioned, three drams of myrrh, and five drams each of aloes and alethil. Grind everything finely together and mix it with alethil water or flour if the constitution is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this poultice.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	Indeed, it is a good compound, healing broken bones quickly and benefiting many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	A method for making a poultice, which also aids in the healing of fractures and sprains.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Recipe for a poultice, which includes measure parts of myrrh and gum, as well as six parts of acacia and twenty parts of Armenian balsam. All ingredients are finely ground together in abundance and sifted, then made into a paste with water or milk: and they are administered.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	A method for using the poultice in cases of dislocations and bones separated from their places: and it soothes the pain that befalls them, as well as the tearing apart of bones, and the breakage.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Wool is taken, cleaned, and submerged in an acetous solution, and then cooked with oil: and it is placed over the area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this poultice, it does not have the virtue of restoration, but it is good for soothing heat-induced symptoms: and it drives away pains specifically.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	A method for using the poultice that restores a fractured bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of the deaf fig, and the leaves of the wild elder: and grind all together, then make a poultice from each.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	A simplified method for using the poultice during bone fracture restoration: and when you wish to resolve the remnants of heat.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Recipe for the root of chamomile, and wildflower, and flowers of mullein, and herb flour, all in one part: grind all together, then make them into a paste with wine if there is no heated member.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is heated, then mix that with water infused with coriander, or just use water, and use it accordingly.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	The method of plastering for a stronger healing process during repair of a member, as opposed to the first one, when there happens to be hard pus at the restoration point.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Recipe for the root of the high plant, seeds of flax, of balsam, of honey rush, of cumin, and of violet flowers, as well as of chamomile. All ingredients are mixed together in equal parts, they are ground and then prepared with willow water or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	The entire thing according to the heat of the member, and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	However, Hippocrates did not say in his book that something should be placed on the broken member during its restoration, other than a catgut made from catgut and oil: nothing else, and he said it should be of medium size between thickness and fineness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	However, Galen prescribes that during the restoration of a broken member, they should be placed on it substances with heat abatement, such as myrrh, frankincense, and similar ones among those we have described.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The method of plastering that strengthens against injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Recipe for the mixture of mugwort, chickpeas, human hair from the incisors or bird feathers, and the root of the high plant; all parts are equal. They should be ground together and sifted, then prepared to make a plaster膏from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The amount required should be one that keeps the bandage in place. Then dissolve it at the time when you can determine whether there is no weak pain, no itching, and the broken mouth does not move from its place: then do not resolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	If there occurs to it itching in that place, or an annoying pain, or swelling: then hasten and dissolve it at the hour, and remove the plaster from him: and take a soft cloth, or a sponge moistened, humid. And immerse it in warm water, and cleanse that place with it until the itching subsides and the pain is settled.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then cut off the member and allow it to rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place a woolen cloth soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose-oiled, over it, and bind it at night for one day until you are free from warm sweating, and let the swelling of the member subside and remove its pain.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then bandage the wound with a thin wrap and use a small poultice. Do not tighten the bandage too much at first, and keep it loose enough until you are healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see pus, redness, pain, swelling, and all other symptoms have disappeared entirely, and you no longer need any dressing or bandaging, then continue as you did at first with an even application.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing of what we said happens to the member, then do not cut it loose, unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when twenty days have passed since it is cut off, according to what you perceive from the condition of the member after its removal, as we said, until when the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh over that place begins: then add more bandaging than your first throughout in the bandage. Also add an increase in the consumption of nourishing food, according to how it has progressed before being reminded.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If you see that the site of fracture has already dried up and weakened more than necessary, then you will know that the food cannot reach there.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore, immerse it with warm water everywhere that you had immersed it, and let this happen in all three days, and relieve the bandage a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Through this operation, nutrition flows to the member and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	That which the foolish restorers do, using an aid for a broken limb when it does not heal as prescribed and then heals according to its curvature, is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it was straight, they would say that this was what the old ones wrote in their books and would operate with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I did not see any trace of theirs there at all, and it is better that this does not happen.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	¶ On the process of occurrence on the head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fracture are various and its figures many: and the causes thereof are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For a fracture that occurs due to impact with an instrument: and the impact removes the entire mouth up to where it reaches the siphac, which is under the bone, like when an ax cuts into wood. Therefore, this type of fracture is named the Axial Fracture.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the blade of a tool hits some part of the bone and the face of it, and does not penetrate to its very end through cutting: and this type of fracture is named the Fracture of Calaan, that is, Absolute Exposure.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is either the wound between two fractures, or large, or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And there is the fracture that results from rubbing or wearing away, and its cause is impact with a stone, or falling upon a stone, or similar occurrences.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this kind of fracture is penetrating as well, which already approaches the membrane that lies beneath the bone; or it is within the surface of the bone. And there is also a wound between these two fractures, whether small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is the fracture that occurs within the bone as thin as a hair: and it's a small crack, and for this reason, this type of fracture is named the Capillary Fracture.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And there is a fracture which occurs by chance or by the impact of a stone and similar actions that cause an intrusion of bone layer into the interior, and it forms a concavity: like happens with iron when they are struck, and part of them gets into the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	And much does happen to bone caps, such as those found on children's heads.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And these are formed with all these species of sutural fractures, and I refer to that entire matter again in its proper place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures through their identification upon them, and examination with tests, and the removal of corrupted flesh that is above them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The species of Capillary is recognized through this: it is found over the bone, removed, and treated with wax: for indeed, the black fracture appears.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the patient's condition. Then, if you observe signs from these conditions that clearly indicate serious illness, such as vomiting, expansion, loss of understanding, loss of voice, convulsions, acute fever, ejection of eyes, and redness to them, along with similar observations from various incidents, there is no doubt they are not healing; and if you see non-threatening incidents, and hope for recovery, then begin the treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	This means, if a wounded person comes to you when they are being wounded, and it is during the winter days: then you must strive for the removal of the bone before the fourteenth day according to all circumstances.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is during the summer days, then you must hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before that which is under the bone from pus becomes corrupted, and those incidents we described occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the fracture of a bone has already reached the membrane touching the brain, and is with details and suction: then it is necessary that you enter the broken part and rubbed, according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And do this, as if you were cutting off the head of a wound: and remove that above the mouth according to whatever possible way for you: and according to the pattern of wounds, and what is slight above the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	And if you happen upon blood flow in the detection of a bone, or a warm pus: then oppose it with what is necessary alongside.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And do this, as if you were filling the space with soaked bandages in wine and rose oil: and let the wound rest until the pus has settled, and be free from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin with the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	Certainly, there is one method, where you cut the mouth with the edge of an incisive tool: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Then apply another Incisor after the wider space of the incisors, and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	And then apply yet another Incisor broader than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second method is that there are several different numbers of Incisors with you: some will be wider than others, and some shorter than others. They should have their ends sharpened and should be made of metal or hardened steel: use them with ease when striking over an Incisor, so as not to strike its head and damage it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If the mouth is strong and hard, then you must pierce around it before you apply the Incisors with what are called Terebras which do not penetrate deeply: they are not called this way just because they do not pass through the end of the bone to that which comes after it. Therefore, since the Terebra is a round end under its sharp head similar to the edge and thin circle prevents sinking and passing through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it is fitting for you to take from these drills a large number, each of which corresponds to the thickness quantity of bone until every drill is available to you: whose tip's sharpness in length and shortness be according to the thickness quantity of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three types of drills, or trepan needles.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	The quality for drilling through a fractured bone is as follows: place the drill over the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been pierced.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then swap the drill to another location and place it with an amount of thickness between all openings equal to that of the radius or roughly this.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut through with the Incisors that are between all openings from the bone: and make this smaller than you can over what is at the end of thickness, as we said, until you remove the bone, or with your hand, or with something else from some tools you prepared for this: like small tongs, and subtle drills.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And you must take every precaution so that the drill or any of the Incisors does not touch the siphon.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When you thus circumvent the bone while drilling and separate it from the siphon, if there is continuity with it and you remove it, you must scrape away and level off the remaining extremity that stays in the bone with another tool similar to an Incisor.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it must be thin and subtle more than other Incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	And if there is anything remaining from the bones and splinters, then take them with ease using what you have from your tools.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then attend to the wound after that, using garlic and ointments as we have said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another mode of operation is easier, very far from fear: this said Galen and greatly praised himself. And this is his discourse.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first, to begin by uncovering the portion of the bone at the place where the fracture is more severe and clearer. Continue until when you have identified that part, and placed under it the tip of this rounded canine tooth, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the rounded portion does not hit anything soft. And its acute part cuts into both sides of it to a length, as you can see: so that the rounded part should be inserted into the canal, with its sharp face hitting the bone from inside.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike above the canine tooth from one side with a small hammer until you enter the entire bone easily, as it revolves: and you should be careful about the cloth, so that nothing happens there that you fear very much.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the surgeon were not a fool among men and more ignorant of it, nor asleep, then if there remained anything attached to the bone from the cloth in certain places, he would strike it off from him with the tip of his rounded canine tooth, and set him free from it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	Indeed, it is freed without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate until the cloth, and what is taken away from the bone is its face, and remaining in it roughnesses and subtle strata: then it must be that you remove that roughness, and uproot those strata with fine rasping tools from which you have prepared a number of different quantities, so that it is possible for you to administer them in every place more suitable for them and straighter for themselves, according to what the operation leads you to and the broken bone, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you administer according to your ratio, which among the first roots of the operation, a larger shaving tool should be used.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use one that is finer afterwards.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not stop doing that until you reach the point where you will administer something finer and more subtle among all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	For each remaining small groove and fine hair, when it comes to breaking or fracture, you need to apply care, according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And it is a matter that does not hide itself from all who study this art, and it stands over what we wrote and showed in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	If however, a wisp of hair is detected and retained when you extract the root: then it is necessary to take a linen cloth, according to the amount of wounds, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another piece of linen, possibly doubled or trebled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, then place it over the first linen: and make this as easily as possible over that, so as not to cool off the scab.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer above it a wide bandage: and do not tighten it, unless its width can hold the wound only: and release it with this care after one day or two days, until you are safe from hot discharge.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it and administer after that medicines with which there is excessive dryness, such as the roots of lily, and herb meal, and thurifer dust, and aristolochia, and similar things: and you should make a powder from these medicines to be applied like powders over the wound.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally apply medicine of everything which has a property that it cleans without biting.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And beware according to your virtue, so that the wound in your care becomes clear: let there be no pus in it, nor impurities.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	And do not let any poison accumulate completely within it: because when a poison accumulates over the brain's dressing, it spoils it and putsrefies itself, and something serious happens afterwards to the sick person. And then it occurs in the opening of the head, when its mouth is cleaned by him, especially when there is neglect of its care, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	So then consider this: if you encounter situations as we have described to you for the sick person, know that it is likely harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur, except due to the medicine that is placed upon him, and it has a property of that medicine which causes that blackness: then you must take one part from honey, three parts from rose oil, and linen with these.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it over the opening: afterwards care for it with the appropriate remedies until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	¶ For the restoration when the nose is broken.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that the nose is not broken unless two of its upper parts are broken simultaneously, or one of them; because there are two bones in it. Because below it is cartilaginous, it does not break and it only occurs due to rubbing, twisting, and other similar factors.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then you should insert four fingers into the nasal aperture and equalize that fracture with your index finger and the thumb of your other hand until the nose returns to its natural shape. And this should be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, that through your operation, no pain befalls the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not reach that finger [a term referring to a specific part or region], then it must be corrected by balancing the extremity of the radius where there is thinness.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	If however the fracture is in two parts, then make it similar to that [some specific treatment or process]: and proceed with the restoration of it on the first day after the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day in a peaceful state immerse it in warm water.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce a linen thread into the extremity of the nose if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two threads if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be in the thread such amount of thickness that it fills up the nasal opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the old restorers said that the linen threads should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That, however, does not seem to me right; rather, it should be that the linen thread is soaked in a paste made from saliva and ground meal.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then remove the linen thread until the mouth becomes firm, and the cartilage hardens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is introduced into the nose instead of the linen thread after it has been covered with a soft cloth. And what happens is that the injured person holds the fracture of the nose more firmly and is not prevented from breathing due to this treatment.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this procedure is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do that: and if you wish, do the linen thread.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If it happens that you are operating on the nose again with a warm poultice, plaster the nose with camphor paste, or with an infusion of rose oil into olive oil, or moderately from urine.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If nevertheless an abscess does not occur hot, then it is necessary, to plaster him with aloe flour, and powder made from thyme with powdery snail.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place a soft wadding on it, and do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If indeed the bones of the nose are fractured slightly or broken, then it is necessary to cut them off and extract them with the suitable instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then sew the cut, and take care of it together with what promotes flesh formation and consolidation from suitable plasters, or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If an ulcer occurs in the nose, then it is necessary to take care of it with lime and administer a lead pipe until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Section on the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken, and the fracture is not accompanied by an ulcer: then observe if it is a fracture of the external part only, and does not break into two parts, and heals towards the inside. Then knowledge of it is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if the fracture is in the right part of the jaw, you should insert your left index finger into the patient's mouth: similarly, if the fracture is in the left mandible, then insert your right hand's index finger. And push it together with that towards the external side with ease, and from there with your other hand you will center the part from the internal part of the bone, making it even.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then it is necessary to administer an extension from both sides according to straightness, until such time as equality becomes possible.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If indeed there is already disturbance or breakage in the teeth, then bind those that you hope will remain with the thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place the saw over the broken mandible.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place over it a double layer of cloth, and place over the cloth a large center-cut piece of leather: or a piece of equal size from the heel skin, with a length equivalent to that of the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above, according to how the preparation of the binding for you and its compatibility with application is done, until it does not cause destruction. And advise the patient to eat gently with tranquility and rest. And provide him mild sips of food.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If however you think that something is being altered by some means to the figure, then act quickly and free it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been altered from that, and plaster it with powder from the mill, mixed with saliva or with millet flour, after you have used the saw: and place over the plaster a soft wool.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While then that plaster remains attached to it, and does not alter the arrangement of the bones, remove it, do not free it until it heals: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Indeed, this kind of fracture is bound for three weeks multiple times.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If meanwhile an abscess should occur, then administer what we said to be done many times during its treatment, until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is accompanied by a wound, consider it carefully.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	If indeed the fragment has already separated from the bone, or from the skin: then consider this carefully, to remove that fragment of the skin with what is suitable for you in its removal from the tools.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If the wound's opening is tight, then enlarge it with a phlebotome according to your need's quantity.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then, when you have removed that much, and nothing remains from them, or then if the wound's opening is large: and if it isn't, place upon it substances suitable for this, and harden that until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	¶ Regarding the restoration of the furca (a type of forceps) when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Title VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	Indeed, the furca (a type of forceps) is often broken at the anterior part from the side of the humerus, and its breakage occurs according to one of three methods.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or indeed it breaks and separates into two parts, beyond which there may be some resistance: and this makes its restoration easier.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or perhaps because of happening within the bone: and this makes its restoration more difficult.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or in this way, which is a break accompanied by a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And the operation in this case when there is a break without a wound, is that you should have two assistants present. One of them holds the tool that follows the broken furca, and the other extends their neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalize the break with your fingers until its shape is formed as needed: and do not allow any prominence or depression in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then you should place under the protruding part of a small sphere made from cloth or wool. The size of this should be according to your needs: extend and lift the furca, and hold onto the sphere with your hand until it equals out the break as needed.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the extremity of the Scapula towards the outside: because it has reached depth, then the patient should be laid on top of his/her own neck. Place the middle pulley underneath one of its shoulders with about the size of a fist, and press the attendant's shoulder downwards until the point that is in depth rises up to the surface. Then correct the fracture and adjust it using your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel the clavicle moving and a popping sound when you move it, then you should hold over it and extract the fracture with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is held within the bone, then you should use your skill in making an incision with one of the prepared incisors you have ready for this. After placing the device that holds the scaphoid under the clavicle: and the device is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It becomes like the ear which does not have a hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	And its width should be according to that which you need it from the size of the bone and its firmness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	As for its length, even adjust it according to what is possible for you for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And may it have two ends, as you see: and one of the ends be broad, and the other be narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If the fracture is wide where you cut it when you extracted the bone of the fracture, and you prepare it with a hot iron: then join two layers of skin to this wound with stitches.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the fracture is small, or you fear an abscess may form: then fill the wound with bandages and grains according to the size of the cut in the wound.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If an abscess becomes hot, then immerse a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	If it is indeed a stricture of the bone without wound and without sectioning, then you place plaster made from mill flour mixed with alkali on the mouth.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft wax over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under the nipple if you need that.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take the hemeatom, that is, a wheel which the Saracens hold, which should be extremely long; and its width should be one hand, or roughly like that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a double thread of wadding over the wax and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take an astral stone from a thin plank whose width is three fingers and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then fold the cloth with the astral stone over the place where it falls on the fracture and the spot.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the hemeatom over the fracture as it is rolled, and fold it over his neck, and under the nipple on him who is healthy, and under the nipple of him who is sick: and make her lie over all parts, and as you see that the stricture holds the fracture in its proper place: and this is what does not hide itself from you, and all together, so that it may not be removed astral stone from under the broken mouth.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, you must observe the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Therefore, whenever the ligament softens and you see that the astral stone has already been removed, then straighten it out, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the sick person on their back and put beneath its belly at night a small amount of milk, so that when it sleeps, its helper will be lifted from its side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the sternum should be treated by lifting the humerus.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Alternatively, fasten the arm to the neck: and do not loosen the bandage if no accident occurs due to itching or dislocation, until twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the dressing if you see that his face is turned towards this.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And apply in the fold, and release him until he recovers and clots.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	The fracture of the sternum is bound and strengthened for the most part within twenty-eight days, and sometimes it occurs in some people in that lesser span.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	Chapter: Restoration of Fracture with a Spoon
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	Rarely does the spoon fracture and at its broad part; it is not fractured from there except from its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	So when it fractures from that place and fractures in the middle of it, and this is not known unless by touch; then according to what the shape of the fracture is, attempt preparation for it.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And return it over to the natural shape in every way that your ingenuity allows, which is possible to you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place over the site grain powder with alkali and a soft soap, and then place above that lint flour from folded cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a broad piece of thin plank according to the size of the spoon or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If there is an indentation under the star (the surgical instrument) in certain places of the spatulaes, then equal that indentation with soft wax, until the star descends according to equality.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then cut from above with an Algerian razor, according to the size and firmness of the star, until it cannot be moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	And examine the ligament every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the ligament softens, tighten it, and if the star is moved from its place, equalize it: and let him lie on his healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	And the spatula is indeed restored within twenty days, or within twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	When this number has been completed, then release the ligament: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is from bones whose union is not feared, nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If however it proceeds from a fragment of bone and pierces under the skin: then cut above it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do what we said about the fracture of the humerus through cold setting, if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	¶ On restoration of fractures in the Chest.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The chest sometimes breaks in the middle of its own extent, and it is rare for this to happen.
