Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he might insert both his thumbs at once, if the dislocation is from two parts.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And let the remaining fingers of his hand be outside those with which he equates.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And instruct the sick person to clean his jaws and lengthen them up to being able to eat everywhere.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the doctor adjusts the jaw, and urges the jaw until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If the return of it is difficult, especially if both jaws are at once: then administer vaporization with warm water and oil, until the return of the jaws becomes easy: do not entirely avoid a timely return of the jaws, as we said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	So when they return and adjust themselves, and the mouth of the sick person closes, and does not soften: then place over them wool pieces with a wick that is made of wax: and an ointment mixed with rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Then it is bound with ease using soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And let the sick person sleep on his back: and his head be placed between two pieces of wool so that he does not move himself to the right or left: nor should he try, or be made to chew anything: instead, soft food is put for him until when the pains disappear and the jaw is fixed: then he can eat what he wants, and it should be administered with ease.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	And do not tire on the operation of his mouth at congestion and drink, and rocking, until the jaw is fixed and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the return of both jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at some hour and do not return to their places, then fevers and continuous vomiting often occur. And perhaps the stomach of the sick person will be relieved, and perhaps it will vomit pure cholera.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you see that: then you will know that there is a loss, and many times that person dies when this happens within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the Reduction of Dislocations of the Furca and the Elbow Joint.
Caput XXVI.	Title XXVI.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The furca (or scapula) is not dislocated from its internal lateral side due to its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	And it may be dislocated externally, and this can be determined by sensation.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And the restoration method is for the patient to lie on his back, and extend his arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then try to restore the position by pressing with your hand, as it will return through its own force.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Next, place plaster and ointment over it, and bind them firmly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	As for the other parts of its extremities which follow the elbow and continue with it, they do not get dislocated except rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	Which does get dislocated on some day: then it should be reduced and levelled according to what we have said, and as what is prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then place plaster and ointment over it, and apply bandages.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the patient to remain calm and still until they have healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with the same procedure, the elbow extremity is reduced when it is also separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On the Reduction of Dislocations of the Shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Title XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the shoulder blade does not get dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of these is for it to be dislocated towards the lower part of the deltoid.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is for it to be dislocated towards the chest area.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps dislocation occurs above the upper part of the humerus: and this happens rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it is not dislocated at the back, due to the shape.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated at the front, due to nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And indeed, many of them get dislocated and come out towards the nipple: especially in those with little flesh.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Because it goes quickly outwards and quickly back in.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those with much flesh, the opposite occurs, that is, it comes out with difficulty and goes back in with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some individuals due to a blow or an accident, and the humerus gets displaced when heated, and is thought to have been dislocated because of that.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	So it is necessary to experience that until you are certain of its nature, and then proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	Dislocation is known when it occurs towards the back of the body relative to the nipple: and you distinguish between a dislocated humerus and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	You will find a clear difference between them and you will discover that there is a concavity in the head of the humerus, and upon touch it seems to be hollow as if part of its body is missing. And an invalid cannot bring his hand to his ear nor move it with all motions.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	Similarly, if it gets dislocated towards the chest or upwards, then you will find a clear palpation, which is not hidden.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And indeed, this kind of dislocation has easy reduction when it is recent or the patient is an invalid child.
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is, that the servant raises his hand to the higher ones.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	Then place your thumbs under his tubercle and raise the suturing with strength upwards to its position: and the servant raises his hand and extends it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	Then place it downwards, for he himself returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If however he does not return through that which we said and there are days at the beginning where a dislocation occurs: then it is necessary for the patient to bathe in warm water, and an application should be given that softens and soothes, just as if the roots of hyssop, and fennel, and sweet clover were steeped in water, and administered.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	Then the patient is put to lie on his back: and under his tubercle a sphere and wool is placed which should be equal in softness and tightness.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	Then the doctor puts his heel on the sphere, and raises the head of the shoulder with strength, and draws the patient's hand downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another servant holds the head of the patient so it does not move downwards, for he himself returns immediately.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if you wish, reduce him according to this manner: and it is that you should make the present man who stands longer than the patient, stand against the side part, and insert his shoulder under the tubercle of the patient: and raise his tubercle upwards until the patient is suspended in the air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another servant pulls the patient's hand downwards towards the lower part of his stomach.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If however the patient is light: then it is necessary to have something else hang with him in order to weigh him down: because the dislocation happens immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced according to another method: and there is one where a piece of wood is formed on the ground that has a round shape as its head: like the handle of a mortar; which should not be thick nor too thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	Then let there be placed under the weak person after placing soft cloths on top of the head of the wood. And make the weak person stand according to the length of the wood.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then extend his hand to the lower part from one side, and extend his body from the other side with strength: for the connection returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If the reduction of him is difficult through all that we have said, then use this care: and there is where you take a piece of wood whose length is the quantity of two arms, and its width is the quantity of four fingers, and its thickness is the quantity of two fingers: to which its head will be round, so that it may fit into the depth of the bed with its opening, according to this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	Then bind soft cloths over the round head so that they do not harm the weak piece of wood.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	Then place the weak person under the bed so that the hand or arm can be extended over the wood up to the lower part: and bind the piece of wood on the support, the arm, and the end of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	Then place the arm on the step of the ladder across its width, and extend the hand to the lower part, and let the rest of the body hanging from the other side be released.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	Indeed, the union takes place immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	And when the insertion of it has been completed according to whatever possible method: then it is necessary that you place under the bed a sphere of equal quantity made of wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	Then put on prepared plaster made of mill dust mixed with olibanum and egg white, covering the whole shoulder as it is rolled out above.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then tighten under the nipple for a proper bandage: and the ligament is moved over the plaster from above. And the hand of him is attached to the neck itself, and it is not moved, neither his hand during seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	And it should be that a small amount of food is placed for the sick few until the member is strengthened: because it is faster to its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then place a larger one after seven days or five, and let him exercise with movement.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If therefore it becomes firm and does not soften, then he is now healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	However, if the joint is dislocated many times, due to moisture that happens to it or for another cause: then it should be treated with a cautery with three holes, according to what was presented in the chapter on cautery.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If this is done completely, and the ligament is released after seven days, and the joint does not harden, and the plaster and bandage are applied repeatedly and do not firm up, and it falls and cannot be lifted to higher positions: then you will know that the nerves which are connected to the shoulder blade have either been cut or stretched, or made soft. And you will know that the joint will never set in its place.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	The dislocation that occurs towards the chest and breasts, or backwards reduction, is done with a push and extension using hands until it returns. Afterwards, any remaining bandage and care are administered until it heals.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing heaviness occurs in the limb and tardiness in its movement, then the sick person should use multiple baths until that heaviness is alleviated and returns to their natural first state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	¶ On the treatment of the dislocation of the elbow.
Caput XXVIII.	Title XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	You know that the elbow joint dislocates with difficulty and similarly returns with difficulty. Indeed, it dislocates to all parts, but particularly towards the front or towards the back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	And its dislocation will not be hidden from you: for it falls under the eye and under touch, being dislocated according to whichever figure [of movement] it is.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join together the dislocated elbow with a healthy one, this becomes clearly evident to you.
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	Indeed, the joint is concave and cannot double the arm or touch its own shoulder with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you must approach and reduce the dislocation immediately before heat blisters occur.
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if heat blisters occur to him, the reduction of it becomes difficult; and perhaps it will not be fully healed, especially when it is towards the back.
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	Indeed, this is worse among all types of dislocations and comes with greater pain to them: and often death descends with it.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the restoration of it when it is possible to reduce from among those that are available, is: to extend his hand with both hands. And his arm must be expanded and the doctor's hands be above the elbow and under it, and he impels the joint with the fingers of his own hands simultaneously, or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or otherwise the dislocation is towards the front: then return it in such a way that he doubles his hand with his own, until he strikes the elbow which is dislocated with the root of his palm.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	And if the dislocation does not yield to reduction, then administer a strong, powerful extension. And it is this: two attendants must extend their arms; and the two attendants also hold him, so that he does not move during the extension.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then cut the arm so that after folding over and covering his hand with a doubly layered piece of cloth or a broad ligament, every part is enclosed.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	And when the doctor touches his own suture with his hand, he should anoint it with oil: so that among those things which help in the smoothness of the suturing process with ease.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then drive the suture forward with a strong thrust until it returns.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And after reducing it, one must place on it a plaster where there is compression and drying with the help of sulfur: and the bandage should be tightened to a proper degree.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	And hang the arm from the neck of the sick person: and release after some days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then release.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If therefore the suture becomes firm in its place, then release the ligament from it and release her.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	And if you see that the suture is not held well, then apply again a plaster and ligament, and release her for some days until it is tightened.
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then release her.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If however weight falls upon her after the reduction of the suture and positioning is in motion: then administer moistening in bathing, and a subtle friction, and compression, until it heals, or place over the suture a paste, that is, a fatty testicle.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it should be bound and released upon her during the day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then remove her and immerse him in a bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	And when he sweats, then rub the suture with a gently rubbed friction.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	Then apply one, and then two, and three tallow pastes together with immersion in the bath until they soften.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	And if you want a wound, place on it a wad of dung, moistened and heated with butter, and bind it over.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	Do that several times.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	Indeed, it softens and returns to its natural state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	¶ On the treatment of dislocations by Al-Mhassem.
Caput XXIX.	Title XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	Al-Mahassem often dislocates the hand, which is the joint between the upper arm and the forearm.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And reducing his dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	In contrast, for all other joints.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	However, it is necessary that the speed be present in reducing his hand dislocation at the time when he dislocates it, before the spot becomes fixed: or an eruption occurs there hot.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of his dislocation is to place Al-Mahassem's weak hand on a board, and have him extend the attendant's hand. And the doctor places his palm over the protuberance of the joint, and pushes it until it returns.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	However, it must be considered if the hand has already retreated to the belly of the hand: then the infirm person places the back of his own hand on a board during extension and reduction. And if the dislocation proceeds towards the back of the hand, then the position of his hand is inherently on the board, that is, the inner part of his hand should be placed on the board so that the doctor's hand falls over its own protuberance of the joint.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, it is good: and if not, then bind it with plaster to cover the eruption. And release him, do not repeat that procedure.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	For if it doesn't tolerate, you cannot continue with his reduction after days have passed, however the joint remains according to its curvature: and it does not harm the sick in any way, except that the hand softens, and she cannot bind anything. Then you will know that the nerves are cut or rubbed.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	Therefore there is no skill in that, except when it is tightened with the cautery near the case of its own.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps this does not bring about anything significant.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	So when Almahassem does not return, then place over it the plaster, as we have described.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then tighten it up, and let it go for five days: afterwards, open it and let it go, and exercise the hand.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	But if her movements are restricted and something becomes heavy there: then soften it with heated water, and perform friction several times, until it softens.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	### Instructions for the Treatment of Finger Dislocations.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When a finger is dislocated from any part of it, or even towards the back of the palm, or belly of the hand: then extend the finger and push against the dislocation with your thumbs until it returns to its original position.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then hold the head of the finger, and hang it towards the part from which it is dislocated, and let it go for two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then hang him up, and extend the finger until it is straightened out on that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	So when it is night, bind him according to that same instruction: and do not stop releasing him each day; and exercise him with movement; and bind him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Perform this for several days until it tightens.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	And do the same if it is dislocated towards the belly of the hand: bind it to that part and perform your first operation on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	And do similarly with him when he is dislocated towards the other parts.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	On the treatment of dislocation of the lumbar vertebrae.
Caput XXXI.	Title XXXI.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When such an event befalls someone, whether it is a complete dislocation of the lumbar or cervical vertebrae, or many vertebrae are moved from their places: then there is no treatment for that, because death approaches the weak.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of this is that the weakness of the sick person escapes without his will, and he cannot hold it; and many times some parts of him soften from it, or both legs of him, or both arms of himself, or one of them: or one of the vertebrae is moved from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Indeed, it happens many times because the removal affects all four parts multiple times.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	So, that which is moved towards the back, is called Humpback.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The treatment for it is to consider whether Humpback occurs during childhood: then there is no treatment for this, and there is no complete recovery from it.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	As for the one that occurs due to an accident, or impact, or by similar means, ancient people have already spoken at length about the methods of treatment.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which many do not return with beneficial results.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I have indeed abbreviated it from that which slightly excuses much of its proximity to my intention and through the explanation I provided for it, and reshaped its tool in a different manner than they showed and explained it.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore, that there is no intelligence nor recovery from the humpback which occurs from the front part.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	And similarly with the one that happens to both sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	And shears are not used on them, except the one which happens precisely in the back, as I am narrating; and it is that the sick man lies face up on a flat board near the wall: and under him is spread a damp cloth so that his chest does not get hurt.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then a straight piece of wood is placed fixed in the ground at a corner of the board, near his head. Another piece of wood is set near his feet, at the other end of the board. The attendant holds the piece of wood, and it should not be firmly planted in the ground.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And another attendant holds the other one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then cover the sick person's head, and bind his forehead loosely, firmly. Extend the end of the ligament towards the wood that is near his head and tie it there.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	Then bind another ligament over his hips, and above the knees, and near his ankles.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather all the ligaments together, and bind them to the other piece of wood which is near his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then all the attendants should spread out over the wood where the ligaments are attached, and do not move the two pieces of wood from their places where they are fixed. However, they should not be firmly fixed as we have said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the doctor should place his hands on the Spondyles (a term used for vertebrae) with strength until he leaves them: or he can place them on that table.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then attach his feet to the table until he returns.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	If however, he does not return through this cure, then take a table whose length is about three spans.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And dig in the wall as we said that is near the sick person, for where the end of the table can enter.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place a middle table above the Spondyle.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the doctor place his feet on the other extremity.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And he should tighten it well until the Spondylus is compressed, and return to its place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	Then, if you have need, to operate with the return which is covered by your hand: and it is that you should prepare two pieces of wood at the end of each foot of the sick person, their length being equal to one arm; and also two pieces of wood at the head of the sick person at the end of each foot.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And let the length be that which is between every piece of wood and one palm: and now a hole has been made in every place through which the return runs; and all the pieces of wood are fixed firmly in the ground, so that they will not move at all.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And the round piece of wood is inserted: and there is the return within which the ligament revolves in two holes of two pieces of wood.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at its extremity is a hole into which the wood is fixed, whose length is equal to that which revolves: and similarly at two other pieces of wood.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	Then, tighten the ligaments that you have tightened in the chest of the sick person which is at the head: and the ligaments that you have tightened in his legs are tightened in the return which is at the feet.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	Then stand by each return as a servant, who shall twist his hand with the licinus, with which the return revolves: and the doctor will balance the Spondylus, as we said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the return, which follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	And after the Spondylus returns and balances its place, then it is necessary to apply a dried plaster with egg white.
Deinde stuppam.	Then the plug.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	Then place above the plaster a star-shaped piece from a board, which width should be three fingers or roughly so.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And its length is as much as it can take the place of Spondylitis, and over the part of healthy Thoracic vertebrae.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	Then it is fastened with the ligament that we said.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the invalid uses fine nourishment until they heal.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If there remains some prominence in the site at the end of healing, then it is necessary that soothing and softening medicines be administered, with the use of the table which we described for a long time.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And now the lead sheet is administered there.
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And sometimes a prominence occurs at the last thoracic vertebrae of the back: and it is thought that through this dislocation, and there is that which now emerges.
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore, it should not happen to assume this with this medicine: perhaps it will result in death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	### On the treatment of dislocated Ankh
Caput XXXII.	Title XXXII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	You should know that the fracture of Ankh and the fracture of the humerus happens only due to dislocation and does not happen like other fractures due to small displacement and concavity.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And indeed, the fracture of Ankh (Ankh is likely a term or anatomical structure in the context) occurs according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	This means, because it can be dislocated towards the front and towards the back.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And mostly it is dislocated towards the inside: and it is slightly dislocated towards the front and back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment for his dislocation towards the inside is: because when you unite the diseased leg with a healthy one, it appears longer. And his knee is elevated more than in health, and he cannot bend his foot near the groin. And there's a place following the groin which follows the diseased bone warm by warmth, since the head of the thigh bone has already arrived there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the sign for him who suffers dislocation towards the outside is that his accidents are contrary to these accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the sign for him who suffers dislocation towards the front is that his healthy leg extends up to a quarter-circle: however, he cannot bend it without pain in the knee. And if he tries to walk, he cannot proceed ahead of the affected area. He retains urine, and the groin becomes swollen. During walking, there is a heel strike due to his foot.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign for him who suffers dislocation towards the back is that he cannot extend his knee, nor can he bend it before the groin bends. His leg on the other side is also shorter. The groin becomes soft and the head of the thigh bone is at the place of the ilium.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The treatment for this type of dislocation, however, is to consider when it occurs, whether the dislocation is new and therefore still present, or if it has already aged.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then, if you perform the reduction and it remains according to its natural position, there is no cure needed for that.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore, it is not necessary for the assumption to be made entirely upon him.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In the case of one whose dislocation is recent and belongs to one of the four types of dislocation: then proceed in this way, trying to straighten it out, extending it both inward and outward, and moving it with your right and left hand. Perhaps it will return to its place without needing further treatment.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If this method does not return the thing, then you must prepare a strong attendant and have him extend his leg from its lower part: either with his hands or with a ligament that is tied over his leg above the knee. And another attendant should extend his hand over it so that he can insert his hands under his nails.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Next, tie with a soft ligament to the coxal bone and hold the end of another's ligament.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let the extension be either from the anterior part of the groin to the iliac crease, or from the posterior part to the dorsal region.
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let the extension of all these be one by each until the patient is lifted up with their body from the ground and remains hanging.
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this kind of extension is the common form of all four species.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If therefore the dislocation comes back with what we said, it is good; and if not, then for each species, there needs to be that which I will say about its own treatment.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In the process of reducing it oneself when the dislocation is towards the inside, one must have the patient lie on their healthy side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then place the ligament over the coxal bone, at the point where it is between the head of the coxa, and the place below the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upwards from the part of the groin to the higher part of the body, towards the iliac crease.
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	Then another strong attendant should take the arms of the patient, and reduce the large place of the diseased coxa, stretching it outwards forcefully.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	Now it has returned to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this is the form of an easier method compared to others for treating and reducing this limb.
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If indeed there is an exception made for you and you do not obey this method of treatment at the entrance when applying to your case, then it should be that two crippled feet are bound simultaneously with strong ligaments, softer ones, above two heels, and above two knees: and let the length of each equal its own size up to four fingers: and let the leg of the sick person be extended further by an amount equivalent to two fingers.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	Then the sick person should be suspended over the head of the wooden pole, which should be placed inside the house. And let its length reach up to two arms from the ground.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command the strong youth to protect the thigh's head and suspend him with the sick person. You find another: And have the other youth push, protecting the thigh with strength; for union returns to its place at speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	When it comes to correcting him to his own position, when the dislocation is towards the outside, you should have the sick person lie on a platform, as we told about in the one with humpiness.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And bind the ligament over his leg, properly to the sick one, and also over his chest.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then place two pieces of wood, one near his feet, and the other near his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then place an additional piece of wood in the middle of the foot, firmly fixed. Cover it with wet cloths so as not to hurt the sick person: and let the wood be between his thighs, so that it does not pull towards the lower parts during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then all assistants should extend to their respective parts and the doctor should adjust the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If therefore he obeys in the reversal, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place her on the table and press her evenly as we said about humpiness.
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	But nevertheless, it is necessary that the patient lie on his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	And when the dislocation is towards the front, then it is necessary that the physician quickly extend the diseased leg of the patient. And he follows this same description on a bench, and places his right hand's palm on the groin of the patient.
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he constrains him with the other hand, and with that constraint, place him extended down towards the back to the knee area.
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	And if the dislocation is towards the back, then it should not be that the patient extends down towards the back and is lifted above the ground. Rather, he should be placed on a hard surface as well, just as it would be necessary even when the outer part of his body is dislocated, according to what we said about him lying on both elbows. And he lies face up with extended ligaments, as we previously mentioned.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	And it is necessary to administer compression with the table even at the point where the joint protrudes, once the reduction has been completed as required.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its return should not be hidden from you: and it is that you extend both legs of the patient. And when you see them equal, and the patient grips his leg, and extends it without any discomfort: then you will know that the member has indeed returned, as required. Then join the two hips, and place the plaster, and compress with a bandage, that is, a hoop, so that the elbow does not move towards any part of the body, and the patient remains quiet for three days or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then release the ligament and plaster, and compare the legs with each other. Then if you see them equal in position, then you will know that the dislocation is now stabilized: therefore allow the patient to walk accordingly.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	And if you see anything of softening: then return, and cover that with the plaster, and bind it according to your first constriction: and let even that be for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then release that and make it remain under walking for a couple of days, until it heals well.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	¶ On Dislocations of the Knee.
Caput XXXIII.	Title XXXIII.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	The knee can be dislocated in three ways.
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	It can be dislocated to the outside, to the inside, and downwards, that is, towards the back.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	And it does not get dislocated to the front.
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	The sign of such a dislocation is that you will instruct the patient to apply their shin bone to their thigh bone.
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	If it does not adhere with the thigh: then you will know that the knee is dislocated.
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	The restoration of all its forms of dislocation is to make the patient sit straight, so that they can now extend their shin bone if possible over it and adhere your back to their face; and place their foot between your own.
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Then adhere the knee of its owner with your palms, and place them straightly between your fingers over its knee.
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Next, apply with your palm the two sides of its knee firmly.
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	And another attendant will extend its foot until the knee returns to its place.
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	The sign of recovery is that the shin bone adheres with the thigh gently, not laboriously.
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Then plaster it, and adhere the shin bone to the thigh.
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then bind them together with bandages for three days or four.
Deinde solue ea.	Then, release those things.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	And let the patient not use walking for a certain number of days until he is healed.
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	But if he refuses you to reduce it, then administer strong traction with ligaments, as was described in the treatment of the humerus, until it returns.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	§ Treatment of Dislocation of the Calcaneous.
Caput XXXIIII.	Title XXXIV.
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	The calcaneous (heel bone) is sometimes reduced with small displacement and at other times dislocated by the full amount.
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	And its dislocation can happen either towards the inside or towards the outside.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	And the sign of its dislocation is that you see the calcaneous swollen and moving towards the part where it is being dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment for correcting its displacement is easy and straightforward: it involves gently stretching it with your hands until it returns to its original position.
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	During the treatment of this condition when it is fully dislocated, you should have the patient sit upright. And a strong attendant should hold the patient firmly from the lower part of his back, in the middle of him.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold his foot with your right hand from the upper part of his foot, and place your left hand under the heel (cauilla) of his foot.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot towards you with your right hand.
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	Then with your left hand, apply two fingers.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend the foot with your left hand and push the front of the foot towards the shin with your right hand without effort.
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do that twice, as we have instructed.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the front of the foot towards the shinbone at three-quarters position, and you pull the heel bone.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If therefore she returns in the belly once, or in two according to this manner, and you see the foot level, it is good: and if not, then repeat the operation on him: because he returns.
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If however the return of it to you is prohibited with what we narrated: then make the sick person lie on his back on the ground, and fix a stake firmly into the earth so that it falls between his buttocks: and you have already covered him with a cloth, so as not to harm the sick.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then take hold of the thigh of him [the patient]. Afterwards, the attendant shall extend another foot, either with his hands or with a ligament that is tied over the ankle bone.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then all the attendants shall extend against the comparison of their own extension: and the stake should stand between the two buttocks of the sick person, holding him so that his body is not drawn down towards the lower parts during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the doctor adjusts the dislocation with his hands, and another attendant holds the healthy leg towards the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with velocity.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When then the dislocation returns and its restoration is shown to you: then apply plaster and swaddling bandage, and bind it firmly with bands, and tie the foot with a band around the thigh.
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And you must, perceive or feel the nerves that are above the heel bone, so that the bandage does not lie heavily on them and harm them.
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then release him for two days, or three.
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the bandage softens, tighten it again: then loosen it on the third or fourth day, and forbid the sick person from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If one wishes to walk before that space, there is no certainty that it will not dislocate upon itself, and become corrupted, and does not receive treatment after that.
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If an inflamed pustule should occur to him: then it is necessary that you administer the thing which precedes our narration in another place concerning treatment and ointment until it is removed.
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	¶ On Dislocation of the Toes, and Treatment.
Caput XXXV.	Title XXXV.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	It should be done that what is dislocated from them is reduced with slight effort during extension; and indeed this is not difficult, but rather easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If the dislocation is in certain parts of the heel bone: then it should be that the patient sits with his foot on an equal place on the ground or on a table: and stands as if walking.
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then stand up, and place your foot over that which extends out from those joints.
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then strike that with your foot with strength until it returns to its place, and you can feel it is correctly aligned, and no longer appears elevated in the location.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under his foot a table which holds the whole foot, having two ends.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	Then apply a bandage appropriately for three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then release him and make him rest from walking for many days until it is bound securely after reduction.
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	¶ On the varieties of dislocations with wound or fracture.
Caput XXXVI.	Title XXXVI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When something like this happens and you attempt to treat it and restore him, many times death occurs. Therefore, one should not assume that his treatment is of this sort unless he is a prudent man skilled in the long practice of medicine, compassionate, pious, slow, not bold or presumptuous: and that he uses medicines for starting treatment which calm inflamed pustules only, and dismisses the patient according to divine judgement.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you have ideas, or hope for salvation from destruction with alleviation of illness, and in which there appears some hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	Therefore, try to reduce it immediately at the beginning of the matter, before a hot pus forms.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If therefore the member returns, according to what we wish, then administer a regime that calms the pus: and care for the wound with whatever is suitable for it from drying ointments.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If there is a dislocation with fracture, and it happens in the case of bones separated from the articulation, then try to remove them, and do what we said about simple illnesses according to what precedes in their places.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And beware according to your virtue, and protect yourself from entering the path of fear: according to what preceded my prediction to you.
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For that is better for you with your Creator, and more enduring for your glory, and more beneficial to your body among them in your time.
